Stocks remained lower Tuesday afternoon after recovery efforts fizzled. Hurt by media and transportation stocks, the S&P 500 was off 0.7%. The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 0.9%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq fell a milder 0.2%, thanks to strength in biotechs. The tech-heavy index briefly reached positive territory earlier. Volume was running mixed. NYSE trade was tracking 8% higher compared with the same time Monday. Nasdaq volume was running 3% lower.In leading stocks, Southwest Airlines (LUV) gapped down and slumped 8% after lowering a key metric. Before the open, the discount carrier said operating revenue per available seat mile (RASM) will be flat to 1% lower in the fourth quarter vs. a year ago. Intraday, the stock fell 4% below a 47.27 buy point from a cup base cleared in early November.Other airlines also came under pressure after performing well Monday. Virgin America (VA) and Spirit Airlines (SAVE) dropped 4% each. United Continental (UAL), American Airlines (AAL) and Delta Air Lines (DAL) fell 3% each.Elsewhere, Outerwall (OUTR) was off its session low, but still off a whopping 24% after announcing a trio of bad news late Monday. The operator of Redbox movie-dispensing kiosks lowered its full-year guidance for earnings and sales and said it will shutter its Sampleit kiosks, where consumers can get sample products and coupons for $1. It also announced the resignation of Redbox President Mark Horak. Shares fell to a three-year low earlier in the stock market today.Leaders up in volume were few, but Adobe Systems (ADBE) rose 2% after reversing. It's now 6% past an 86.09 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The software giant will report fiscal Q4 earnings after Thursday's close. The software giant is expected to post 60 cents a share, up 67% from a year ago.Follow Vincent Mao on Twitter @IBD_VMao.

The major averages fell again Tuesday, though they closed well off their session lows. The Dow Jones industrial average shed 0.9% and the S&P 500 fell 0.6%. The Nasdaq, boosted by biotech and software stocks, edged 0.1% lower. Volume was mixed, running higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq, according to early figures.

Losers topped winners by more than 2-to-1 on the NYSE and by a 3-to-2 margin on the Nasdaq. Biggest decliners in the stock market today included transportation, metal ore miners and building-related stocks. Auto parts retailers, medicals and software makers outperformed.Southwest Airlines (LUV) gapped down and sank 9% in fast trade. Before the open, the discount carrier said operating revenue per available seat mile will be flat to 1% lower in Q4 vs. a year ago. The stock fell as much as 6% below a 47.27 buy point from a cup base cleared in early November.Toll Bros. (TOL) slumped 7%, slicing its 50-day moving average in heavy trade after the homebuilder's fiscal Q4 earnings missed views. Revenue, however, came in above forecasts. The stock has been consolidating since mid-August.IBD 50 builders D.R. Horton (DHI) fell 1%, while LGI Homes (LGIH) reversed upward for a 1% gain after recovering from a near 5% early loss. LGI is still well below its 50-day line, which it gave up Monday during an 11% plunge.Citrix Systems (CTXS) led the IBD 50 on the upside, rising 3% to retake its 50-day line and a 76.38 buy point. Shares of the software maker triggered a sell signal last week after falling 8% below the entry.Desktop software maker Adobe Systems (ADBE) reversed upward for a 2% gain. It's now extended from an 86.09 cup-with-handle buy point. Analysts expect Adobe to earn 60 cents a share, up 67% from a year ago, when it reports Thursday after the close.Smith & Wesson (SWHC) surged 5% in massive trade, padding its 8% gain from Monday. The stock marked a new high and is far extended from a 19.07 cup-with-handle buy point. The firearms maker was down after hours despite reporting fiscal Q2 earnings above views.Economic data slated for Wednesday include the Mortgage Bankers Association's mortgage applications and the Energy Information Administration's weekly petroleum status report, both for the week of Dec. 4.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo and on Facebook.

Adobe Systems (ADBE) said Thursday it plans to buy ComScore's (SCOR) Digital Analytix business to add to its Marketing Cloud offerings.San Jose, Calif.-based Adobe expects the acquisition to close in December. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.Adobe is buying the technology assets and customer accounts of the Digital Analytix business. The employees associated with Digital Analytix will continue to be employed by ComScore. Adobe and ComScore plan to sign a transition service agreement under which those employees will continue to provide services to Digital Analytix customers.The Digital Analytix business will be added to the Adobe Analytics unit of the Adobe Marketing Cloud. Adobe Analytics provides customers with real-time data analytics and detailed segmentation across their marketing channels.Online traffic measurement firm ComScore, based in Reston, Va., is streamlining its operations ahead of its $732 million acquisition of Rentrak. ComScore looks to become a bigger player in measurement services for media companies and online brands.The Digital Analytix deal was announced in a press release about ComScore's Q3 earnings. In the September quarter, ComScore earned 2 cents a share, vs. a year-earlier loss of 10 cents a share, on sales of $92.4 million, up 14%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected ComScore to earn 5 cents a share on sales $94.2 million.On a non-GAAP basis, ComScore earned 43 cents a share in Q3, up 5%."In addition, we are announcing today that Adobe is acquiring our enterprise analytics technology, Digital Analytix," ComScore CEO Serge Matta said in a statement. "This divesture improves our competitive position, allowing complete focus on our mission to make audiences and advertising more valuable across all the screens that matter."ComScore was up more than 5%, near 46, in afternoon trading in the stock market today. That's significantly below the company's all-time high of 65 reached on Aug. 17.Adobe stock was down nearly 1%, near 90.50, in afternoon trading. It hit a record high of 91.85 in morning trading.RELATED:Adobe Systems 2016 Guidance Clouds Growth Story.

Cyber cash registers rang up a record $3.08 billion worth of goods Monday, as shoppers went long on electronics and toys, according to an Adobe Systems (ADBE) survey. Cyber Monday discounts averaged 21.5%, which drove sales, according to the Adobe Digital Index. Of the $3.08 billion in sales, $799 million were completed on mobile devices, a 59% increase over 2014.…

No. 1 online retailer Amazon.com (AMZN) drew more than a third of Americans' Black Friday and Cyber Monday e-commerce spending by one estimate, while a Wednesday tally called Cyber Monday the heaviest U.S. online spending day in history.Amazon, however, actually appears to have lost a little Cyber Monday market share.Official numbers aren't in from Amazon yet on holiday sales, but by analytics firm Slice Intelligence's tally, Amazon accounted for 35.7% of e-commerce spending on Black Friday, Nov. 27, followed by Best Buy (BBY) with 8.2%, Macy's (M) with 3.4%, and Wal-Mart (WMT) at 3.3%.Amazon's Black Friday share was way up from 31.5% last year in the tally, and Slice estimated that Amazon Black Friday sales rose 23.2% from a year ago.Slice spokeswoman Jaimee Minney told IBD that Cyber Monday "was bigger than Black Friday and bigger than Cyber Monday last year."The Black Friday estimate comes primarily from an analysis of about 876,000 email receipts provided by Slice's panel of 3 million shoppers.Amazon garnered a 36.1% share of U.S. e-commerce sales on Cyber Monday by Slice's estimate, down 2.7 percentage points from a year earlier.Also by its estimate, "the retailer's sales were down 1.3% vs. the same day last year," Minney said in an email.Wal-Mart was the only store in the top five to gain share on Cyber Monday by that tally — up half a percentage point, to 3.8%.Cyber Monday SoarsWednesday, online tracker comScore said Cyber Monday reached $3.12 billion in online spending, up 21% from last year's Cyber Monday.ComScore's mobile figures aren't final, but it said desktop online spending set a record, at $2.28 billion.ComScore said that for the first 30 days of the holiday season, $27.9 billion has been spent online by desktops, up 6% from a year ago."The weekend after Thanksgiving also reached a major milestone as it saw its first ever billion-dollar online shopping day on Sunday," it said in a report Wednesday, "while Saturday sales reached the $1 billion mark for a second year in a row."Overall, Cyber Monday online sales set a record with $3.07 billion in spending across the U.S., up 16% from last year, according to Adobe Systems' (ADBE) Adobe Index, as Amazon leveraged its e-commerce dominance. But Thanksgiving weekend sales looked weak at brick-and-mortar retailers.Apple (AAPL) iPad and iPhone doorbusters were hits for Target (TGT) and others, while Wal-Mart announced booming mobile sales.Retail analytics provider ShopperTrak, however, estimates that U.S. physical stores took in 10.4% less than a year earlier over Thanksgiving, Black Friday and the weekend — an estimated $20.4 billion that does not include Cyber Monday.Amazon's Black Friday showing wouldn't be out of line with the IBD Leaderboard company's heft in online shopping — the company "makes up about 69% of total U.S. retail traffic," Canaccord Genuity analyst Michael Graham said in a research report this week. Minney said Amazon's Black Friday crowd "doesn't surprise us."Amazon said that it had a record Thanksgiving weekend for selling Amazon devices, triple last year's result. Its top-selling products across all those available on Amazon.com on Black Friday were Amazon devices, the company said — No. 1 was Fire (its tablet line), and No. 2 was the Fire TV stick for streaming video online.Where People Shop OnlineIn October, the latest month tallied, Amazon drew over 160 million online visitors, up 19% from a year ago according to comScore (SCOR) and Canaccord estimates. Next-up eBay (EBAY) drew about 88 million (up 12%), Wal-Mart 84 million (up 32%) and Target almost 69 million (up 15%).Amazon's rise was "meaningfully fast," Canaccord analyst Graham said in a research note Tuesday.Graham noted that Amazon stock is the best-performing name in his coverage area and has more than doubled this year.Follow Donna Howell on Twitter @IBD_DHowell.RELATED VIDEO:Shopping Surges Online: What's Hot, What Flopped?

Stocks held moderate gains going into the noon hour Wednesday, with energy stocks leading the way on a sharp rise in oil prices. The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the S&P 500 rose 0.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average lifted 0.8% in the stock market today. Volume was tracking higher than at the same time Tuesday on both the NYSE and Nasdaq.

Among IBD's 197 industry groups, energy groups were among the best performers. The U.S. oil and gas producers group rose 6%. Oil futures rose more than 3% after the government said oil stockpiles declined unexpectedly, signaling a rare reprieve from the oversupply that has driven down prices. OPEC also said it expects oil prices to rebound.

Despite a cheery earnings report and an after-hours pop Tuesday, Nike (NKE) reversed and headed lower. It was down 2% in above-average volume and struggled to hold its 50-day moving average even though several analysts had good words for the stock before the open. It's trading below a 133.62 buy point it cleared a few weeks ago.

Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) gapped down and was trading at a four-year low, off more than 4%. Before the open, Wedbush Morgan lowered its price target on the stock to 48 from 62. The stock has broken below 50, to the lowest since August 2011.
Among IBD 50 stocks, Veeva Systems (VEEV), a newcomer to the list, was the best performer, up 2%. The cloud-based medical software maker is forming a long base.
Another IBD 50 newcomer, electric utility ITC (ITC), also rose 2% and is forming a base. It has received multiple analyst upgrades in recent weeks.

Red Hat, the No. 1 provider of open-source Linux software, late Thursday posted fiscal Q1 earnings and revenue that beat Wall Street estimates. Red Hat (RHT) gave mixed guidance for the current quarter, however, with EPS a bit short and revenue a bit above analyst estimates at the midpoint of its guidance. Red Hat stock was down 1.5% in after-hours…

Technology and retail ETFs levered up Tuesday as IBM (IBM) and Adobe Systems (ADBE) reported massive online sales over the holiday weekend. Shoppers using mobile devices reportedly accounted for more than half of all online traffic at sites such as Amazon.com (AMZN) and Alphabet 's  (GOOGL) Google. Stock market analysts say Internet-connected smartphones and tablets are continuing to transform…

Mobile commerce sparked Cyber Monday as it did Black Friday and the start of a holiday season in which online sales are outperforming last year's.From midnight through 3 p.m. EST Monday, online sales were up 18.1% from the year-earlier period, according to IBM (IBM). That's way up from IBM's tally of an 8.5% sales gain for full-day Cyber Monday last year.Mobile users accounted for 46% of all online traffic, up 16% over 2014, IBM said."Mobile continues to be the story," Anuj Nayar, senior director of global initiatives at online transaction company PayPal (PYPL), told IBD.Adobe Systems' (ADBE) Adobe Digital Index, which says that it measures 80% of transactions for the top 100 U.S. retailers, projected U.S. Cyber Monday sales to hit $3 billion and be the largest online sales day of the year.Adobe said that mobile traffic accounted for 53% of shopping visits and 32% of sales.ITG analyst Steve Weinstein told IBD he sees three trends:• Heavy shopping has started earlier in the season.• Mobile buying has changed shopping behaviors.• And retailers, especially Amazon.com (AMZN), that have heavily invested in fulfillment infrastructure, will do well and lengthen their selling season.From Thanksgiving Day through Sunday, U.S. shoppers spent $8.03 billion online, up 17%, says Adobe. Baird analyst Colin Sebastian wrote in a research note that initial shopping data appears "positive" for Amazon, Google owner Alphabet (GOOGL), ChannelAdvisor (ECOM) and PayPal."We're all pretty excited here," Scot Wingo, executive chairman of ChannelAdvisor, told IBD. ChannelAdvisor tracks third-party sales on e-commerce sites such as Amazon and eBay (EBAY).Big-screen and ultrahigh-def (4K) TV sets are among this year's top sellers, says IBM's Justin Norwood."In particular, Samsung seems to have hit a chord across the 4K picture and sound price point, and has taken a leadership position," Norwood told IBD.The Apple (AAPL) Watch is another big seller, "but that trend goes back three months now, from our data," Norwood said.Hoverboards — single-axle, self-balancing scooters — also are hot. EBay says that it sold two hoverboards a minute on Thanksgiving. "If there were a breakout item, that's it," Hal Lawton, senior vice president of eBay North America, told IBD.ChannelAdvisor reported that as of 3 p.m. EST, Cyber Monday sales were up 16.8% over the year-earlier period, but a small percentage from last year's growth.EBay "is offering very unusual promotions," said Wingo. "They seem to be saying that we're going to opt-out of competing with the big guys on the latest GoPro (GPRO) camera, for example."ChannelAdvisor said third-party sales were up 22% at Amazon but less than 2% at eBay, though it represents just a small percentage of eBay sellers.Lawton, in a statement, said eBay is making "an aggressive push" for daily deals on Apple products.No. 4 U.S. retailer Target (TGT) suffered a website outage at 10 a.m. EST Monday on heavy traffic. The company ran an aggressive promotion, offering 15% off any item on its website. Target had to get a lot of product makers onboard for such an offer, Wingo said, "and that required a lot of planning in advance."PayPal, too, suffered a morning outage that Nayar described as brief, declining to go into detail.

As the official start to the holiday shopping season arrives, Americans are using their mobile devices more than ever to capitalize on Thanksgiving and Black Friday deals online.On Thursday and early Friday, mobile traffic accounted for nearly 60% of all online shopping traffic, and 40% of all online sales, said Justin Norwood, product strategist for IBM (IBM) Watson Trend, which analyzes online shopping data.Shopping via Apple (AAPL) iPhone and other smartphones was about triple tablet shopping, IBM says."Both on the hits side and on the sales size, the smartphone is outpacing tablets, and smartphone shoppers dominate," Norwood told IBD. "It seems like this is the breakout year for mobile optimization, and retailers have invested a considerable amount in their mobile sites."It takes a considerable investment (to optimize for mobile sales), but prior to doing so the shopper experience on a phone (was) very difficult."The strong sales are a generally good sign for e-commerce stocks like Amazon.com (AMZN) and PayPal (PYPL). According to ChannelAdvisor, which tracks third-party selling on e-com sites, third-party Amazon.com sales were up 20% year over year for the start of the season, but eBay (EBAY) sales were down 10%.Shares of Amazon and PayPal, however, both fell a fraction in Friday's shortened session, while eBay stock rose a fraction.Adobe Systems' (ADBE) Adobe Digital Index, which measures 80% of all online transactions from the top 100 U.S. retailers, found that 37% of online sales for the early part of Black Friday came via mobile, mostly smartphones.Hal Lawton, senior vice president of eBay North America, told IBD that mobile sales were strong on that site. "We sold a limited edition Mercedes on an Android phone, a Lamborghini on an iPhone, and a Ferrari (RACE) Testarossa on an iPhone," he said.EBay says mobile growth is the trend. "For us, mobile is not a new story," Lawton said. "For Q3, we saw 43% of traffic on mobile. And we're seeing shoppers start on one platform, like a phone, and then finish shopping on another, like an iPad."But Adobe said online sales were lagging its estimate. Sales between midnight and 11 a.m. ET Friday rose 15% from the year-earlier period to $822 million, it said, but Adobe had expected 19% growth. Adobe is anticipating $2.6 billion in online sales for Black Friday.On Thanksgiving, email promotions accounted for 14% of online sales, says Adobe, rising 25% from last Thanksgiving.Adobe's report also found that eBay surpassed Amazon.com in social media buzz."We're very pleased by the results we saw on Thanksgiving, and we're pleased with the early momentum today," Lawton said.

Criteo (CRTO) stock dove on Wednesday after the Paris-based ad-tech firm gave Q3 earnings and Q4 guidance below Wall Street's expectations before the market open. Criteo stock closed down 16.3% in the stock market today, at 35.05. Criteo stock is down 13% this year and is off 42% from its all-time high of 60.95 touched in early March2014. Criteo reported…
Stocks rose and closed just off their session highs Tuesday after staging a reversal that lifted the major indexes out of the red.

The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each closed with an 0.6% gain, while the Nasdaq added 0.5%. Volume was slightly lower across the board in the stock market today, according to preliminary data.

Advancers topped decliners by about a 3-2 margin on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE. The Dow outperformed with the help of a 2% rise by UnitedHealth Group (UNH) on reports that the managed care firm is mulling a merger with Aetna (AET), which gained 3%.

After the close, Adobe Systems (ADBE) was down nearly 1% after reporting fiscal Q2 earnings that topped views by 3 cents a share. Revenue rose nearly 9% to a quarterly record $1.16 billion. The stock had gained 1% during the regular trading session.
Traders may be sitting on the sidelines, waiting to see the results from the Fed's two-day monetary policy meeting, which wraps up Wednesday.
In economic news Tuesday, May housing starts data came in below forecasts, but building permits were higher than expected.
Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.

Stocks traded quietly and slightly higher going into the noon hour Wednesday as investors awaited word from the Federal Reserve on the future course of interest rates.
The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average were up 0.1% and the S&P 500 was slightly higher in the stock market today.
The Fed is scheduled to release its policy statement at 2 p.m. ET, and Fed chief Janet Yellen has scheduled a 2:30 p.m. news conference.

Automakers were the top-performing group, thanks to Tesla Motors (TSLA), which was up 3%. It broke out of a cup-with-handle base that goes back to last September. It cleared a 258.85 buy point., The company announced an exclusive partnership with Jeff Dahn, a professor at Dalhousie University in Nova Scotia known for his work in lithium batteries.
Among IBD 50 stocks, 30 were higher and 20 were lower.
YY Inc. (YY), operator of a Chinese social media platform, rose 6% in big volume. The volatile stock is building the right side of a long, deep base.
CyberArk Software (CYBR) rose 4% to a new high as it emerged from a ragged cup-with-handle base.
Carpet maker Interface (TILE) rose 5% on volume. It was the subject of the Stock Spotlight article in this morning's IBD.

Stocks moved out to a healthy start Wednesday, rising in soft volume ahead of this afternoon's Fed policy announcement.

The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each pecked out 0.2% gains. The Nasdaq rose 0.3%. Volume was down a bit more than 15% on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Tuesday.

The Federal Reserve's policy announcement at 2 p.m. ET is likely to remain the central focus of the stock market today. Oil prices held their early gains, up almost 2%, ahead of the Energy Information Administration's weekly inventories report at 10:30.

In stocks, FedEx (FDX) warped down almost 3% after reporting weaker-than-expected fiscal fourth quarter results. Management guided full-year earnings in line with expectations, forecasting increasing pricing power and continued moderate economic improvement. FedEx has been carving through a shallow consolidation since December.

Adobe Systems (ADBE) slumped slightly less than 2%. Late Tuesday, it reported fiscal second quarter earnings above consensus views, but management's Q3 earnings and revenue guidance disappointed analysts, as the company ramps up its conversion to a cloud-based business model. The stock has been hovering just below an 80.40 buy point following a three-month flat base.

Baidu (BIDU) rose 2% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Silicon wafer maker SunEdison (SUNE) gained 2% and once again led the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index. Oil-related stocks held nine of the top 10 best early gains on the S&P 500.

More than four in five stocks on the IBD 50 list moved higher at the open. At the top of the list, YY (YY) jumped 5% and Noah Holdings (NOAH) climbed 2%. As more viewers step away from their TVs to watch video content on mobile devices, Apple (AAPL) and its iOS system are becoming even more dominant, according to a report released Thursday by Adobe Digital Index, a research unit of software maker and digital ad services provider Adobe Systems (ADBE). The Apple iOS system's share of consumers' premium video viewing…
Major averages extended their gains in afternoon trade after reversing higher from an early drop.
The Dow Jones industrial average led with an 0.7% gain, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 each rose 0.6%. Volume was tracking slightly higher on the Nasdaq but lower on the NYSE vs. the same time Monday.
Cosmetics and personal care, generic drugmakers and food stocks were among the biggest gainers in the stock market today.

Hain Celestial Group (HAIN) rose 4% in twice normal trade as it continued shaping a flat base with a potential 66.46 buy point. Bank of America/Merrill Lynch added the natural foods company to its US1 List of top ideas, according to TheStreet.com.

Natural Health Trends (NHTC) rallied 8% to a multiyear high in brisk turnover. The stock is on track for a seventh straight advance. The network marketer of skin care and other personal care products said Monday that it will join three Russell indexes after the close on June 26.

Also in the cosmetics/personal care group, Coty (COTY) triggered the eight-week hold rule as it soared as much as 20% on news that it had won an auction to buy hair care and beauty lines from Procter & Gamble (PG) in a $12 billion deal.

Cavium (CAVM), up nearly 2% in heavy volume, remains in buy range from a 73.90 double-bottom buy point. Credit Agricole began covering the fabless chipmaker with an outperform rating and an 85 price target, as did CLSA.
Among IBD 50 stocks up in volume, Arista Networks (ANET) gained 3%, Paycom Software (PAYC) 5% and Vasco Data Security International (VDSI) 4%.
Adobe Systems (ADBE) was up nearly 2% in above-average trade ahead of its fiscal Q2 report after the close.

Among the more curious items seized from the Pakistani compound of Islamic terrorist Osama bin Laden was a strategy guide to the first-person shooter video game "Delta Force Xtreme 2."The guide to the 2009 military combat game for Microsoft (MSFT) Windows PCs was among the trove of documents recovered during the raid in which U.S. Special Forces killed bin Laden on May 2, 2011. The video game guide was disclosed in the latest tranche of declassified documents that the U.S. Office of the Director of National Intelligence released Wednesday.The "Delta Force Xtreme 2" guide, as well as a "GameSpot Video Game Guide," were listed under a category suggesting that compound residents other than bin Laden used them.The discovery of the guide raises some interesting questions. Did bin Laden and his cohorts use the game and the guide for training purposes or to study U.S. combat strategy? Or was it simply entertainment at the isolated compound?The idea of al-Qaida terrorists playing a video game in which the elite U.S. Army squad Delta Force are the heroes is odd. U.S. Navy SEALs in an operation carried out by the CIA killed Bin Laden and his crew.Privately held NovaLogic, which counts Electronic Arts (EA) as an investor, made "Delta Force Xtreme 2." The game scored poorly with game critics, getting a Metacritic rating of 40 out of 100. The plot of the game has Delta Force soldiers sent to Asia to bring a drug cartel and former Soviet mercenaries to justice.The Navy Seal raid also scooped up a library of software and technical manuals, most notably Adobe Systems (ADBE) media creation software. Bin Laden's bookshelf included manuals on Adobe Acrobat, Dreamweaver, Encore, Photoshop and Premiere Pro.

Black Friday's importance as the key shopping day of the year is ending, observers say, as Thanksgiving Day sales zoom and easy mobile shopping makes other days just as important. The strong trend of online sales growth far surpassing offline sales continues, though. Cowen analyst Oliver Chen estimates that while online traffic during Black Friday weekend will rise 20%…

Adobe Systems (ADBE) stock sank Wednesday after the digital media software company forecast fiscal 2016 sales and profit below estimates.Late Tuesday at its annual analyst meeting, Adobe said it expects fiscal 2016 revenue of about $5.7 billion, well below the average estimate of $5.93 billion among analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Adobe also forecast an adjusted profit of $2.70 per share, vs. Wall Street's target of $3.19. Adobe's fiscal 2016 starts Nov. 28.Adobe stock was down 5.5% in afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 80. Its shares hit an all-time high of 87.25 on Aug. 18.The San Jose, Calif.-based company said it expects its digital-media and marketing-cloud business segments each to post 20% year-over-year revenue growth next year.In its three-year forecast, Adobe expects total revenue to grow at a compound annual rate of 20%. It sees adjusted earnings per share growing at a compound annual rate of 30% over that time period, from fiscal 2015 through 2018."Adobe is the only company that brings great content and powerful data together, enabling millions of customers globally to build high-impact digital experiences," Adobe CEO Shantanu Narayen said in a statement. "We are targeting 20% revenue and 30% non-GAAP earnings compound annual growth rates between fiscal 2015 and fiscal 2018 that reflect our business momentum and growing addressable markets."Analyst 'Even More Bullish'Most analysts remained upbeat despite Adobe guiding down estimates for next year."Adobe held their annual analyst meeting yesterday and we came away even more bullish on Adobe than we have been," Rosenblatt Securities analyst Kirk Adams said in a research report Wednesday. Adams rates Adobe stock as buy with a price target of 112.Adobe's lower-than-expected fiscal 2016 figures were attributed to foreign exchange headwinds and the impact of customers moving from perpetual license software to subscriptions, Baird analyst Steven Ashley said in a report Wednesday.Ashley reiterated his outperform rating on Adobe stock with a price target of 85.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brendan Barnicle said he has increased confidence in Adobe's long-term prospects after the meeting. In a report Tuesday, Barnicle said he sees opportunities for improved profit margins over the next three years. He rates Adobe stock as overweight with a price target of 90.Adobe said its total addressable market could be $48 billion in 2018, up from $35 billion in 2016. The $48 billion TAM figure includes $17 billion in digital media, $4 billion in Document Cloud and $27 billion in digital marketing, Barnicle said.Adobe's higher TAM makes "significantly higher assumptions" for potential users of its Creative Cloud software vs. previous estimates, Deutsche Bank analyst Nandan Amladi said in a report Wednesday.Adobe sees the potential for 28.6 million users, up from about 13 million users of its legacy Creative Suite product in 2012. The higher user estimate includes more lower-end users, international subscribers and even conversions of people using pirated Adobe software, he said.Amladi reiterated his buy rating on Adobe stock and raised his price target to 90 from 85.Credit Suisse analyst Philip Winslow came away unimpressed with Adobe's forecast. He maintained his neutral rating on Adobe stock and cut his price target to 65 from 75. He said the company's "fuzzy subscriber math" clouded the Creative Cloud business.RELATED:Adobe Systems Profit Margins Predicted To ClimbAdobe Systems jumps after investors reconsider Q3 earnings.

Amazon.com (AMZN) kicked off the holiday season 25 days before the day after Thanksgiving, once the season's traditional start, giving shoppers access to its Black Friday deals.As of Monday, shoppers were able to access the e-commerce leader's Black Friday Deals Store, which will be available through Dec. 22. This year Amazon.com has decided to double the number of "Lightning Deals" — and Prime members will be able to access those 30 minutes earlier than regular shoppers.Amazon, though, isn't the early bird. On Sunday, retail leaders Wal-Mart (WMT) and Target (TGT) launched their holiday pushes.Amazon stock was up a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 628, after touching an all-time high above 630 on Friday. Amazon.com has an IBD Composite Rating of 97, with 99 being the highest.The online retailers' July 15 holiday called "Prime Day," exclusively for Prime members, beat its Black Friday sales in 2014. The shopping event bumped Q3 revenue up by two percentage points, which contributed to the company's third consecutive quarter of escalating revenue year-over-year revenue gains. The company's Q3 revenue jumped 23% to $25.4 billion, beating analyst expectations."Prime is certainly a huge factor" in the growth, Wells Fargo analyst Matt Nemer told IBD. "What's amazing on this scale is to see it (revenue) accelerate. If I had to isolate one (reason for faster growth), it's the adoption of Prime and utilization of Prime, driven by the incremental attributes of Prime."Amazon's Amazon Prime service gives members such perks as free two-day delivery and access to its video streaming service, for $99 a year.According to a forecast by Adobe Systems (ADBE)'s Adobe Digital Index, U.S. online sales on Cyber Monday — the Monday after Black Friday — will reach $3 billion, up 12%. It says online Black Friday sales are expected to rise 15%, to $2.7 billion.
Adobe Systems (ADBE) stock is near an all-time high, but still has room to run, Rosenblatt Securities analyst Kirk Adams said in a research note Thursday.
Adobe stock hit a record high of 87.25 on Aug. 18. Shares fell a penny shy of 86 on Wednesday, but in morning trading in the stock market today, Adobe was down 1.5%, near 84.
Adams reiterated his buy rating on the digital media software company, with a price target of 112.
Adobe stock surged last week after the San Jose, Calif.-based company reported better-than-expected fiscal third-quarter earnings.
Adobe's Q3 results were "outstanding," Adams said. "They beat earnings estimates and revenues, and each of their followed metrics were positive."
He was particularly enthused about operating profit margins, which expanded to 27.5% from 18.9% a year earlier.
Adobe is seeing continued strength in subscriptions to its Creative Cloud and other services, he said.
"Because subscriptions are selling so well, it is driving better (annualized recurring revenue) overall, and both deferred revenues and bookings are strong," Adams said.
He predicts recurring revenue will reach 85% of sales by the end of fiscal 2017, on or near Nov. 30, 2017, from the current 72%.

Adobe has three cloud computing businesses: Creative Cloud, Marketing Cloud and Document Cloud. The biggest is Creative Cloud, which features such popular software programs as Photoshop and Illustrator.Adobe Systems (ADBE) stock is near an all-time high, but still has room to run, Rosenblatt Securities analyst Kirk Adams said in a research note Thursday.Adobe stock hit a record high of 87.25 on Aug. 18. Open-source software has come a long way — just ask Red Hat. The leading maker of the Linux operating system, Red Hat (RHT) announced a partnership last week with its once-bitter rival, Microsoft (MSFT). As part of the deal, Red Hat will provide the Windows creator with its enterprise version of Linux for use as the "preferred choice" on Microsoft's…

The desktop software industry group was the best performer Wednesday, with a gain of more than 2%. But it was due mainly to the performance of a single, hardly noticed IPO that has soared. That company, Code Rebel (CDRB), a so-far profitless Hawaii-based software maker, came public with an offering price of 5 and closed its first day of trading…
Major averages were mildly higher near midday Tuesday as Greece and the start of the two-day Fed meeting remained focal points.
The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq picked up 0.3% each. NYSE volume was tracking slightly lower than Monday. Nasdaq volume was slightly higher.
Generic-drug makers, managed-care firms, and food and beverage stocks outperformed. Transportation and mining stocks lagged.
In economic news, May housing starts data disappointed, but building permits came in better than expected. IBD's homebuilding group fell 0.5%.
In the stock market today, Tesla Motors (TSLA) added 0.6% as it works on a cup-with-handle base with a 258.85 buy point.
Meanwhile, shares of Coty (COTY) jumped 19% after reports surfaced that the beauty products maker is on the verge of acquiring Procter & Gamble's (PG) Wella hair-care unit and two beauty lines.
Cantel Medical (CMN) added nearly 2%. The stock is showing resilience after reporting strong earnings last week.

Elsewhere, Aetna (AET) jumped closed to 3% after the Wall Street Journal reported the company was approached by UnitedHealth (UNH) about a possible merger. UnitedHealth was the best percentage gainer in the Dow, rising nearly 2%.

Major averages rose to session highs in late-afternoon trading Tuesday as the two-day Fed meeting got underway and Greece talks remained stalled. The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.6%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq picked up 0.5% each. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking a touch lower than Monday's levels.The Dow outperformed thanks to a nice move in UnitedHealth Group (UNH). Shares rose 2% after published reports said the company approached Aetna (AET) about a possible merger. Aetna also rose 2%.In economic news, May housing starts data disappointed, but building permits came in better than expected. IBD's homebuilding group slipped 0.4%.The two-day Fed meeting concludes Wednesday. The policy statement will be released at 2:00 p.m. ET. According to CME Group FedWatch , futures traders say there's a 64% chance rates will be raised before the end of the year.In the stock market today, Apple (AAPL) edged higher by 0.3%, shaking off mixed comments from Pacific Crest Securities.Inside the IBD 50, Monster Beverage (MNST) jumped 4% after the company was added to Citigroup's "Focus List." Coca-Cola (KO) currently has a 16.7% stake in Monster.After reclaiming a 35.96 buy point Monday in light volume, IBD 50 name Paycom Software (PAYC) jumped about 4%. The buy range extends to 37.76.Meanwhile, tech services firm CDK Global (CDK) surged about 10% after the company announced plans to streamline its business to increase profitability.Elsewhere, Adobe Systems (ADBE) rallied just over 1% ahead of its earnings report after the close. It's been trading tightly above its 10-week moving average, just below an 80.40 buy point.
Stocks fought to hold thin gains in early trade Tuesday as the market battled concerns over the eurozone's standoff with Greece .
The Dow Jones industrial added 0.1%. The S&P 500 was flat and the Nasdaq showed fractional losses.
Volume was off to a soft start, dipping 10% on the NYSE and 1% on the Nasdaq compared with trade at the same time Monday.

The stock market today received mixed news from the homebuilding sector, with the Commerce Department reporting that new housing starts stalled in May, but building permits jumped more than expected. That coincided with news from the National Association of Homebuilders on Monday that builder confidence had unexpectedly surged in June.
Leading stocks showed some verve in Tuesday's early going.

Monster Beverage (MNST) popped nearly 4% at the open. Coca-Cola (KO) on Monday closed its $2.15 billion purchase of a 16.7% stake in the company. A statement from Coke said that, as part of the deal, it would transfer its worldwide energy business to Monster, including brands such as NOS, Full Throttle and Burn. Coke would take over Monster's nonenergy business, including Hansen's Natural Sodas and Juice products and Peace Tea. Monster fell out of a flat-base pattern and has been working since May to regain its 10-week moving average.

Coty (COTY) grabbed headlines, spiking 16% on news that it would buy the beauty and hair product businesses of Procter & Gamble (PG) in what is being reported as a $12 billion deal. Brands included in the deal were said to include Max Factor, Clairol and Cover Girl. The heavy-volume gain lifted shares 17% past a 25.86 flat base buy point.

Vasco Data Security (VDSI) jumped 4% out of the starting gate. Tigress Financial initiated coverage on the Oakbrook Terrace, Ill.-based security software developer with a buy rating. The report said Vasco's products were simple to implement and use and that demand for network security was increasing. The gain put Vasco shares 18% above a 28.27 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Methode Electronics (MEI) tumbled 8%, carving below its 50-day moving average and undercutting a 47.51 flat-base buy point by almost 8%. Robert W. Baird downgraded the stock to neutral from outperform, citing a weakening outlook, particularly in Methode's automotive business, for the next 12 months.

Stock futures continued to whittle losses early Tuesday, despite a mixed reading on May homebuilding activity.
Dow futures hung 29.2 points below fair market value, nearly halving their earlier losses. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 13.1 points and also well off lows. S&P 500 futures were down 5.9 points.

The stock market today received disappointing news from the Commerce Department, which reported new housing starts held steady in May. The annualized rate of 1.036 million starts was effectively even with April's rate, but below consensus views for an uptick to 1.090 million.
The data on permits issued was more positive, rising to a rate of 1.275 million. That was above April's 1.143 million, easily besting forecasts for a 1.105 million pace.

The Federal Open Market Committee swings into its two-day meeting in Washington, D.C., this morning, but the market spotlight remains intently focused on the eurozone's challenge to manage a faltering Greek economy.

Greek officials reportedly said they had no plans to offer new proposals. Eurozone leaders were contemplating an emergency summit on Sunday, and investors began bracing in earnest for what might follow a Greek default on its $1.8 billion payments owed to the Washington-based International Monetary Fund at the end of June.
The IMF has been pressuring to let Greece restructure some of its debt, Reuters reported, but eurozone lenders resisted such a compromise.

Sovereign bonds, particularly those in peripheral economies, including Greece, Spain and Italy, continued to sell off on Tuesday. The European Central Bank had ramped up its bond-buying initiative this month to try to counteract the effects of the Greek crisis. But broad-based selling has driven yields on peripheral bonds back to levels seen before markets began anticipating the ECB's bond-buying initiative in March, according to the Financial Times.
European stocks were under moderate pressure at midday, with the leading indexes in Paris, Frankfurt and London showing losses of less than 1%.
On U.S. markets, small biotech companies once again dominated the most dramatic premarket action.

Aerie Pharmaceuticals (AERI) soared 45% after the Food and Drug Administration agreed to a shift in parameters in Aerie's trial of its glaucoma treatment Rhopressa. Avalanche Biotechnologies (AAVL) toppled 50%.

The Menlo Park, Calif.-based biotech announced Monday that a trial of its AVA-101 treatment for wet macular degeneration met primary endpoints, but William Blair downgraded the stock to market perform from outperform. The note said the trial showed mixed results with regard to secondary targets.

In nondrug action, fragrance and cosmetics giant Coty (COTY) spiked 16% ahead of the open. News reports said the New York-based firm had aced a deal to buy Procter & Gamble's (PG) hair care units in a deal valued as high as $12 billion. Coty has been near new highs, sitting just above a 25.86 flat-base buy point for the past two weeks.

Leading stocks were mixed and generally quiet ahead of the open. On the IBD 50 list, Vasco Data Security (VDSI) showed some early initiative, rising a bit less than 2% in premarket trade. The stock ended Monday 13% above a 28.27 cup-with-handle buy point.
At the low end of the list, YY (YY) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) lost less than 1% apiece.

In China, the Shanghai composite tanked 3.5%, pressured this week by an onslaught of new IPOs that are raising questions of liquidity. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index slipped 1.1%. In Japan, the Nikkei 225 dimmed 0.6%.

The dollar rose. Oil prices inched up, with West Texas Intermediate futures holding below $60 per barrel. Gold dipped a fraction. Stock futures pointed to a weak start Monday as the market headed for the last trading day of August and the final week of the summer.
Dow futures traded 105 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 23.7 points and S&P 500 futures showed a 13.3-point loss. All were off early lows.

The stock market today launches with the Nasdaq down 5.9%, the S&P 500 off 5.5% so far in August, tracking toward the worst monthly performance for both indexes since May 2012. But it could have been much worse.
The Nasdaq opens 60% of the way up the month's trading range, after rebounding from a 16% dive. The S&P 500 opens just below the midpoint in its trading range for the month.
The market remains in a correction. Savvy investors can put the pause to good use by building watch lists of stocks with strong fundamentals forming possible bases.
A fairly light week of economic news gets the Federal Reserve's September Beige Book report due out Wednesday, and ramps up to the Labor Department's August payrolls report on Friday.
Today, Kingsbury International reports its Chicago Purchasing Managers Index for August at 9:45 a.m. ET. The Dallas Federal Reserve delivers its regional manufacturing survey at 10:30 a.m.
In stocks, the second quarter earnings season is mostly passed, with only a handful of big names - mostly retailers- expected this week.

New Jersey-based biotech Medicines Co. (MDCO) popped 20% ahead of the open. Early stage trial results presented in London on Sunday showed the shot-administered cholesterol treatment ALN-PCSsc - developed with partner Alnylam Pharmaceuticals (ALNY) - lowered LDL cholesterol levels by an average of 64% for more than 140 days. The results suggest a drug that could manage cholesterol levels through shots two or three times a year. Alnylam rose a fraction before the open.

Leading stocks were under some early pressure, with the bulk of the IBD 50 list steering mostly lower in premarket trade. Losses were mild, however. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Alaska Airlines (ALK) slipped furthest, falling less than 1%.

Overseas, China's markets posted a moderately mixed session with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index up 0.3% and the Shanghai Composite down 0.8%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dived 1.3%. Europe's markets were also mixed, with the leading indexes in Paris and Frankfurt down a half percent, and London's FTSE 100 up 0.9% near midday.

The dollar eased vs. the euro and the yen. Bonds edged higher. Oil prices slipped in the 2% range, with West Texas Intermediate trading above $4 a barrel and Brent crude near $49. A couple of bad apples hindered $18.8 billion MainStay Large Cap Growth Fund in the first quarter. Adobe Systems (ADBE) reported better-than-expected sales and earnings for its fiscal first quarter late Tuesday, but investors focused on one number that disappointed: new subscribers to Adobe's Creative Cloud.The media software company added 517,000 net new subscribers to its Creative Cloud, up 28% year over year and bringing the total to 3.97 million subscribers. But Wall Street analysts were looking for 573,000 additions for the quarter ended Feb. 27.Adobe stock was down 3.5%, below 77, in midday trading on the stock market today."We think it was a good number, but people would have liked to have seen more," Adobe Chief Financial Officer Mark Garrett told IBD. "It was a really good quarter and if you're going to focus just on the 517 (thousand new subscribers), you're missing the bigger story anyway."Creative Cloud subscriber additions in Q1 were reduced by a reporting change, he said. With the launch of the company's new Document Cloud, Adobe is no longer lumping Acrobat subscribers in with Creative Cloud subscribers, he told IBD."That change had a significant impact on the subscriber number for Creative Cloud in the quarter," Garrett said.A better figure for investors to focus on is Adobe's annualized recurring revenue, he said. That number has been increasing since Adobe began its transition to an Internet cloud business model. Annualized recurring revenue reached $2.09 billion in Adobe's digital media businesses last quarter.Adobe's Q1 also showed that the company is becoming more profitable now that it is emerging from its transition from pay-upfront software to pay-as-you-go software."If you look at the revenue and earnings we generated this quarter, it really shows that the P&L is coming back in a very big way, which is terrific," Garrett said. "We're through the financial part of this transition."Adobe earned 44 cents a share, excluding stock-based compensation and other items, for its fiscal first quarter, up 46% from the year-earlier quarter. Sales rose 11% to $1.109 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Adobe to earn 39 cents a share on sales of $1.085 billion.For fiscal Q2, Adobe expects adjusted EPS of 44 cents on sales of $1.15 billion, at the midpoint of its guidance. Analysts were modeling 48 cents and $1.18 billion, but Adobe is known to be conservative with guidance.Adobe has three pillars to its cloud strategy: Creative Cloud, which includes creative professional software like Photoshop and Illustrator; Marketing Cloud, which provides online marketing tools; and Document Cloud, which extends Adobe's Acrobat and PDF standard."Adobe is an arms dealer to the creative and marketing worlds," Rosenblatt Securities analyst Kirk Adams said in a research note Wednesday. "The growth of the Creative Cloud and Marketing Cloud should provide investors with good returns over the next few years. We are excited to see revenues rebound this year as the transition to a mostly subscription and recurring revenue model is nearing completion."Adobe also is managing operating expenses tightly, which helps with earnings, he said. Adams rates Adobe stock as a buy.

Adobe Systems late Tuesday posted its best quarterly earnings growth in more than four years, but investors were looking for more green in its forecast. Adobe (ADBE) earned 44 cents a share, excluding items, for its fiscal first quarter, which ended Feb. 27, up 46% from a year earlier and topping Wall Street's target by 5 cents. Sales rose 11%…
Adobe Systems (ADBE) hopes to kick off its fiscal year on a positive note Tuesday when it reports Q1 earnings after the market close.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the San Jose, Calif.-based company to earn 39 cents a share, excluding items, on sales of $1.085 billion. That would translate to year-over-year growth of 30% in earnings per share and 8% in sales. On a GAAP basis, Wall Street is targeting EPS of 20 cents a share.
If results come in as expected for the quarter ended on or near Feb. 28, it will mark the second straight quarter of accelerating earnings and sales growth for the media software company.
For its fiscal second quarter ending in May, analysts are modeling for Adobe to earn 48 cents a share excluding items, up 30%, on sales of $1.175 billion, up 10%.

Adobe is transitioning its creative software business, which includes Photoshop and Illustrator, to a cloud computing business model using its Creative Cloud. It also is expanding its online marketing software and services business called Adobe Marketing Cloud.

Adobe stock hit a record high the day after it reported better-than-expected Q4 results in December. About two months later, on Feb. 27, Adobe reached its current all-time high of 80.30. Adobe shares closed up a fraction Friday to 77.62.
Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brendan Barnicle said his firm's recent channel checks for Adobe's Creative Cloud and Marketing Cloud show that business remains solid.
"As a result, we have increased confidence in the company's ability to at least meet current expectations when it reports FQ1 (Feb.) results next Tuesday," he said in a note Thursday.
Barnicle rates Adobe stock as outperform, with a 12-month price target of 85.
On Tuesday, the company rolled out the latest advances to its Marketing Cloud platform.

Adobe Systems saw sales and earnings growth accelerate in the third quarter as its business transition to the Internet cloud took hold. Adobe (ADBE) late Thursday said it earned 54 cents a share excluding items in its fiscal third quarter of 2015, beating Wall Street's target by 4 cents. Revenue also beat views at $1.22 billion, vs. the $1.21 billion predicted by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
Adjusted earnings per share rose 93% year over year in the quarter ended Aug. 28, vs. a 30% gain in Q2 and 47% in Q1.
Sales rose 21% year over year in Q3, vs. 9% in Q2 and 11% in Q1.
Adobe said the results were driven by strong Creative Cloud adoption and record Marketing Cloud products and services revenue.
On a GAAP basis, including stock-based compensation and other items, it earned 34 cents a share, vs. 9 cents a year earlier.
But Adobe management offered guidance for the current quarter below Wall Street targets.

For the fiscal fourth quarter, Adobe expects to earn 59 cents a share minus items, up 64% year over year, on sales of $1.3 billion, up 21%, based on the midpoint of its guidance. Analysts were modeling for EPS of 64 cents a share ex items on sales of $1.36 billion.
Adobe stock fell about 3% in after-hours trading. In the regular session Thursday, Adobe dipped a fraction to 80.31.

"Our record Q3 financial results set us up for a strong fiscal 2015," Adobe Chief Financial Officer Mark Garrett said in a statement. "Our recurring revenue has reached 73% of total revenue, providing a strong foundation for long-term growth."

Adobe has been moving its businesses from perpetual software licenses to subscriptions and cloud-based services. Adobe has three cloud computing businesses: Creative Cloud, Marketing Cloud and Document Cloud.

Creative Cloud includes well-known products for creative professionals such as Photoshop, Illustrator and InDesign. Marketing Cloud provides online marketing and advertising services. Document Cloud expands on Adobe's popular online document-sharing product Acrobat and its ubiquitous PDF format.
Adobe added 684,000 net new subscribers to its Creative Cloud business in Q3, bringing its total to over 5.33 million subscribers.
Annualized recurring revenue in its digital media units (Creative Cloud and Document Cloud) grew to $2.65 billion. Creative Cloud accounted for $2.3 billion.
On a conference call, Garrett said Adobe's overall business remains strong across key product segments and geographies.
"We continue to drive large portions of our legacy perpetual businesses to a recurring model, and this shift has improved the overall, long-term health of our business," Garrett said.
Adobe continues to perform well and its guidance was likely overly cautious, Edward Jones analyst Josh Olson told IBD.
He rates Adobe stock as hold, seeing the firm as fairly valued.

"They continue to execute pretty flawlessly," he said. "The guidance was a little light. But in terms of the current quarter, the continued cloud adoption is very strong and that was above our expectations in subscriber counts and recurring revenue."

Adobe stock has lifted as investors have gravitated to the company's compelling cloud business transition. Olson said he is looking for the next catalyst to drive the stock, which could be its Marketing Cloud business.

Adobe stock has risen 245% since the company first announced its Creative Cloud initiative on Oct. 3, 2011. The company holds an IBD Composite Rating of 83 out of a possible 99.Adobe Systems saw sales and earnings growth accelerate in the third quarter as its business transition to the Internet cloud took hold. Nike (NKE) showed off several new products at its investor day on Wednesday, from iridescent shoes to tights with kinesiology tape-style elements that "reduce muscle vibration." But a significant driver for the athleticwear company might not be what it makes, but how it makes them.

Its newly announced design and manufacturing center, 3D printing partnership with DreamWorks Animation (DWA), and manufacturing partnership with Flex are all part of Nike's self-proclaimed manufacturing revolution, which aims to ramp up the process of creating and bringing new products to market.

"NKE continues to uncover opportunities to drive innovation via its category offense and improved segmentation, but we were most encouraged by its manufacturing initiatives," wrote FBR analyst Susan Anderson in a Thursday note. FBR raised its price target to 126 from 120.
"It is combining product and manufacturing/supply chain development functions, which could be a powerful margin driver (accelerated product and automated manufacturing innovation)," she added.
The Manufacturing Revolution Will Be Digitized

Furthering its commitment to automation and 3D printing — already prevalent in its automatically knitted Flyknit shoe fabric — the company's Advanced Production Creation Center will be a 125,000-square-foot hub at its Beaverton, Ore., headquarters for designers, engineers and material scientists to create new products.
"Nike's gonna blow the socks off of automation," Macquarie analyst Laurent Vasilescu told IBD.

Footwear and apparel manufacturing is one of the most highly labor-intensive industries, he noted, and "pretty archaic" compared with other more automated industries. Cutting back on labor needs would take some pressure off the company's gross margin, he said.

In an upgrade from traditional cut-and-sew manufacturing, Nike said its budding 3D digital design system with DreamWorks will be capable of "nearly instantaneous digital print applications, photo-real 3D visualizations and ultra-rapid prototyping."
Hopes are high for 3D printers from companies like ExOne (XONE), Stratasys (SSYS) and 3D Systems (DDD) to make a splash in the consumer market.

Stratasys and Adobe (ADBE) announced a partnership last week to allow Photoshop Creative Cloud users to use Stratasys' self-service site to receive 3D-printed items within days. And 3D Systems makes a 3D photo booth, where users can make their own figurines.
Nike shares finished up 2.3% in the stock market today, hitting a record intraday high of 129.17. Shares of 3D Systems rose 3%, ExOne climbed 7.5% and Stratasys notched up 0.9%.
Saving $1 Billion In Costs

Aside from sounding very cool and futuristic, all of that 3D printing and automation technology has an additional purpose: to help save Nike money in leftover materials that don't wind up in the final product. The company said Wednesday that reducing waste alone could produce $1 billion in cost savings.
Even achieving half of that target "represents about 200 bps of gross margin," which could help Nike reach 50% in gross margin, said Vasilescu.

Focusing more on "speed to market and linking near-term trends with the product design process and a more rapid production cycle will increase the likelihood that Nike will continue to be viewed as an innovator in the marketplace," wrote Credit Suisse analyst Christian Buss on Thursday.
Management, often mum about its patent portfolio, said Wednesday that it is the third largest design patent holder in the U.S.

"They probably hold more patents than all their competitors combined," said Vasilescu. Nike is likely shedding some light on patents now to "clearly show that they're building a competitive moat around this business."
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.

The stock market closed at session highs Thursday, making one of its best showings in weeks. The Nasdaq rallied 1.8% and closed at the firmest level above its 50-day moving average since August.
The S&P; 500 added 1.5%. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.3%. Small caps also did well: The Russell 2000 jumped 2.1%.
Volume was higher, according to early figures. Winning stocks led losers by more than 4-to-1 across the board.
A few high-rated stocks broke out, enhancing the solid performance of the stock market today.

WNS Holdings (WNS) broke out past the 31.60 buy point of a base-on-base pattern in heavy volume. The business service outsourcing firm beat profit expectations Thursday with a 13% rise in adjusted earnings per share.
Adobe Systems (ADBE) made a new attempt to clear the 86.09 buy point of a cup with handle.

Third-quarter earnings of note came from Goldman Sachs (GS). The bank's earnings of $2.90 a share and revenue of $6.9 billion missed views and were lower from the year-ago period. Yet Goldman reversed higher to close with a 3% gain.
Citigroup (C)also rallied, adding 4%. The bank topped profit estimates but missed on revenue.

On Friday, earnings are expected from industrial giants General Electric (GE) and Honeywell (HON). The latest industrial production report comes out just before the market's open. The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index is released later in the morning.

A slack session swept into a rally Wednesday afternoon, following the Federal Reserve's rate policy announcement.The major indexes reversed higher on the news, sending the Dow Jones industrial average up 1.3%, the S&P; 500 to a 1.2% gain and the Nasdaq up 0.9%.The stock market today finished in higher trade according to preliminary figures, with volume up 17% on the Nasdaq and 28% higher on the NYSE.As expected, the Fed dropped the "patient" qualifier on the timing of a possible interest-rate hike. It also lowered its estimates for growth and inflation, and said it would need to see further improvement in jobs and inflation before implementing a rate increase.The result sent the dollar skidding lower vs. the euro. Oil prices erased early losses and surged, leaving Brent crude up 4.5% for the session and West Texas Intermediate futures with a 2.7% gain.In stocks, oil, steel and mining issues posted the best gains among industries for the day. The top 10 advances among S&P; 500 stocks were oil or mining related. At the bottom of the list were Charles Schwab (SCHW) and Regions Financial (RF).Also at the rump of the index, Adobe Systems (ADBE) ended more than 3% lower after its fiscal first quarter sales and earnings cleared analyst consensus, but growth of subscribers in its Creative Cloud online offerings disappointed expectations. The stock pared losses after finding support at its 10-week moving average.Virgin America (VA) slumped 7% after Credit Suisse initiated coverage with an underperform rating and a 31 price target. The stock has been trying since early February to build a floor on its chart.On Thursday, Lennar (LEN), Michaels (MIK) and Nike (NKE) are among a few notable companies reporting earnings. Weekly jobless claims, the Philly Fed survey and leading economic indicators will be also be out Thursday.

Google's Q1 missed views as costs escalate for an Internet company tackling everything from wireless services to driverless cars, but currency issues played a role in the miss, and sales growth stayed solidly in the double digits.Google (GOOGL) stock, which has stagnated the past 18 months, was up 4% in after-hours trading Thursday, after the company released its results. Shares rose 1.5% in the regular session to 557.46. The stock is up 5% this year but down 8.5% since touching a 13-month high near 609 last July."Excluding the net impact of foreign currency headwinds, revenue grew a healthy 17% year on year," Patrick Pichette, Google's outgoing CFO, said in the company's earnings release. "We continue to see great momentum in our mobile advertising business and opportunities with brand advertisers."Google doesn't break out mobile revenue. Ads account for roughly 90% of total revenue.The company reported earnings per share minus items of $6.57, up 4.8% from the year-earlier quarter. Revenue minus TAC, the traffic acquisition costs that the company pays other sites to carry its ads, rose 14% to $13.9 billion. Total revenue rose 12% to $17.26 billion.FactSet Research had modeled revenue ex-TAC of $14 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected EPS ex items of $6.60 on total sales of $17.69 billion.As per its custom, Google doesn't give guidance. FactSet expects Q2 revenue ex TAC of $14.5 billion, up 14%. TR expects Q2 EPS ex items of $6.77, up 11%.The U.S. dollar resulted in a negative currency impact of $795 million in Q1, Pichette said on the company's earnings conference call with analysts. He said the gross impact was $1.1 billion, but Google's currency hedging helped.The Internet search leader is up against rivals such as Facebook (FB), China search leader Baidu (BIDU) and China e-commerce king Alibaba Holdings (BABA), among others. Facebook Q1 revenue, posted late Wednesday, also missed, hurt by currency issues.Q1 R&D; costs jumped 29.5% year over year, and sales and marketing costs rose 19%. Operating expenses as a percentage of total revenue rose to 37% from 35% in Q1 2014.Google saw its U.S. search share slip in March to 64.4% from 64.5% in February after being replaced by Yahoo (YHOO) as the default search provider for the Firefox Web browser.That 64.4% was "the lowest since we began tracking this metric in January 2012," wrote RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney in a pre-earnings research note. While the drop "does not give a sense of the performance of either its international or mobile segments," he pointed out that the contract for default search engine for Apple (AAPL) iOS is up for bid soon.For Q1, Google reported a 13% increase in the number of paid clicks, the times a user opens a Google ad, and a 7% decline in cost-per-click, or what advertisers pay on average per click. Late Tuesday, Yahoo reported a 21% rise in its search ad clicks and a 3% decline in CPC.Cost per click in general has fallen as the percentage of mobile ads rises, analysts say, with advertisers willing to pay less for mobile ads than desktop ads. But Pichette, on a conference call with analysts, said the clicks and CPC metrics do not reflect difficulty monetizing search on mobile.A rise in automated ad buying also hurts Google, says Tamara Gaffney, principal analyst with Adobe Systems' (ADBE) digital index report. "Before, you'd just spend on Google because they had the most traffic. Now, the quality of that traffic is becoming more critical," Gaffney said, and Yahoo and Microsoft's (MSFT) Bing search "has always delivered higher conversion rates and more affluent customers to websites."Meanwhile, on April 15, the European Commission charged the company with violating antitrust laws and also said it was looking into Google's Android mobile operating system.On Wednesday, Google launched its first wireless service, Project Fi, which will first automatically connect to a free public Wi-Fi service.
Adobe Systems (ADBE) has added a third pillar to its Internet cloud-based services strategy.

The media software company Tuesday announced its Document Cloud, which expands on Adobe's popular online document-sharing product Acrobat and its ubiquitous PDF format. Document Cloud joins Adobe's Creative Cloud and Marketing Cloud businesses.

Adobe is pitching the Document Cloud as a modern way to manage critical documents at home, in the office and across devices. It hopes to eliminate waste and inefficiency associated with the document process, especially steps that involve paper printouts.
Adobe is looking to make electronic signatures mainstream by including e-signing technology in its next version of Acrobat, called Adobe Acrobat DC, and in its free Adobe Reader.

Acrobat DC also uses Photoshop imaging technology to convert any paper document into a digital, editable file. For example, a parent can take a photo of a school permission form with a mobile device and turn it into a digital file that can be filled out, signed and emailed.

"We really want to eliminate that print out, sign and fax back part of everyone's world," Kevin Lynch, senior vice president and general manager, Adobe Document Services, told IBD. But more importantly Adobe wants to streamline business processes through more efficient document workflows, he said.

Document Cloud consists of a set of integrated services that use a consistent online profile and personal document hub. People can create, review, approve, sign and track documents whether on a desktop or mobile device. The Document Cloud also will connect with other cloud services, such as Box (BOX) and Microsoft's (MSFT) Office 365.

Adobe Document Cloud and Acrobat DC are expected to be available within 30 days. Acrobat DC will be sold as both a subscription and a perpetual license upon availability. Subscriptions to Acrobat DC cost $7.50 to $14.99 a month, with the professional version being the top tier. Adobe also will offer enterprise versions with premium workflow capabilities.

Acrobat DC will be sold as both a subscription and a perpetual license upon availability. Subscriptions to Acrobat DC cost $7.50 to $14.99 a month, with the professional version being the top tier. Adobe also will offer enterprise versions with premium workflow capabilities.RELATED:Adobe EPS Growth Best In 4 Years, But Outlook SoftAdobe Systems expands reach of marketing cloud
The stock indexes closed with gains of more than 1% Monday, boosting a rebound that began last week.
The Nasdaq rallied 1.2%, the S&P 500 1.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1.3%. Small caps lagged, with the Russell 2000 rising 0.5%.
Volume fell, based on the early figures. Still, breadth was favorable. Winning stocks led losers by 9 to 5 on the NYSE and about 9 to 7 on the Nasdaq.
Health-care stocks led the way, as Amgen (AMGN) and other pharmaceuticals announced promising test results on a new generation of anti-cholesterol drugs.
Semiconductor and security software stocks — two well-performing areas — also ranked among the day's best in the stock market today.
Energy stocks lagged as the price of crude oil hit a six-year low.

On Tuesday, the housing starts report comes out before the opening bell. A late rebound helped the broad averages turn big losses into small gains Thursday. The S&P 500 rose 0.2%, while the Nasdaq edged up 0.1%. They were off by as much as 1% and 1.3%, respectively, at Thursday's lows. The 30-stock Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%. According to preliminary data, volume ended mixed in the stock market today. NYSE trade rose and Nasdaq volume fell.

Among leading stocks, thinly traded Tyler Technologies (TYL) surged 10% to an all-time high in fast trade. The Plano, Texas-based IT software and services provider announced it was buying privately held New World Systems for $670 million in cash and stock. Tyler is featured in the latest New Highs column.

Verisk Analytics (VRSK) gapped above its 50-day line and rallied nearly 6% in huge turnover. The provider of actuarial and underwriting data to insurers will be joining the S&P 500 index after the close on Oct. 7. Verisk is shaping a flat base with a 79.98 buy point.
On the downside, Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) gapped down and dived 11% on expectations of weak comp sales and news of store closings.

Spice maker McCormick & Co. (MKC) took heat after reporting disappointing Q3 earnings. The stock tumbled 4% but trimmed losses after finding support at its 200-day moving average. The stock is working on a base.

Stocks pared losses in the last hour of trade Tuesday to close off their session lows. The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 1.1%, the S&P 500 shed 1.2% and the Nasdaq fell 1.5%. Volume was mixed, running higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary data.Losers trumped winners by nearly a 4-1 ratio on both exchanges, as few industry groups were spared in the sell-off.Gold miners, drugmakers and transportation stocks lagged in the stock market today, while those advancing included discount retailers, auto-parts sellers and desktop-software makers, thanks to a reversal in Adobe Software (ADBE).Adobe gained 2% in higher volume, extending its advance for a third straight session. The uptrend kicked off Friday, after the digital media software company late Thursday reported fiscal Q3 results that topped views, though Q4 guidance was disappointing.AmSurg (AMSG) also bucked the downtrend with a 1% gain in above-average volume. The stock, up 15% from a 72.95 flat-base buy point cleared in early August, has found support at its 10-week line. The ambulatory surgery center operator is one of two stocks in the outpatient/home care group with a 99 Composite Rating.Carnival (CCL) sank 5% as it sliced its 50-day moving average in fast turnover. The stock has displayed some wild and loose action in its current consolidation. The cruise ship operator reported Q3 earnings that topped views, but its Q4 guidance fell short of forecasts.On the IBD 50, 38 stocks declined, 11 advanced and one was unchanged. Drugmakers took the biggest hit, with Horizon Pharma (HZNP) and Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) losing 12% and 6%, respectively.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter @IBD_NGondo.

Stock futures spun to deep losses ahead of Friday's open, as further oil price declines continued to pressure global markets. Dow futures dived 172.8 points below fair market value and had held steady over the prior hour.

Nasdaq 100 futures dropped 36.5 points, slightly off their hour-earlier lows. S&P 500 futures were steady, down 18 points. Small caps were taking their share of the heat, with Russell 2000 futures down 14.1 points.

The stock market today took its early licks from oil prices, which backed down nearly 2% after the International Energy Agency confirmed prior forecasts that 2016 average demand growth for oil will slow to 1.2 million barrels a day from the estimated average of 1.8 million bpd this year.
West Texas Intermediate held just above $36 a barrel and Brent crude traded a tad above $39; both were down more than 9% for the week.

The news release and oil price drop hit after markets closed in Asia, but Europe's stocks pulled back sharply. The DAX in Frankfurt was down 1.9%, and the CAC-40 and FTSE 100 in London were down more than 1% each near midday. All are tracking toward losses of more than 3% this week. China's markets closed with moderate losses. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan gained 1%.

In U.S. economic news, producer prices rose 0.3% in November, the Labor Department reported. That was up from a 0.4% slip in October and well above expectations for no change. Core prices, minus food and energy, also rose 0.3%, above views for a 0.1% uptick.

November retail stopped just short of expectations, rising 0.2% — better than October's 0.1% gain but below views for 0.3%. Autos and gas were a negative for the month. Stripping out those categories, sales rose 0.5%, topping forecasts for a 0.3% gain.

At 10 a.m. ET, October business inventories numbers from the Commerce Department are due out, and the University of Michigan releases its December Consumer Sentiment Index. Oil prices might get a stir after 1 p.m., when Baker Hughes (BHI) is scheduled to report its weekly rig count.

Stocks listed on the Dow Jones industrial average were nearly unanimously negative before the open. DuPont (DD) again sank to the bottom, with a 4% decline, after announcing it formally agreed to merge with Dow Chemical (DOW), creating DowDuPont — a $130 billion chemical juggernaut. The companies expect the deal to close late next year.

A large share of downward pressure on the S&P 500 were energy-related stocks. But the contest for the index's worst premarket decline was among DuPont, Staples (SPLS) and Red Hat (RHT), all down in the 4% to 5% range.

At the top of the list, glass maker Corning (GLW) surged 8% on news of the Dow/DuPont deal, under which Dow Chemical will assume 100% ownership of Dow Corning, a 50/50 joint venture between Dow Chemical and Corning.

Adobe Systems (ADBE) popped 5% after delivering a solid fiscal fourth-quarter report late Thursday. Earnings were above expectations, revenue in line and Q1 guidance below consensus forecasts. But strong growth in the company's cloud-based business and a rise in recurring revenue, to 74% of Adobe's total take, pleased investors.
The stock ended Thursday in a test of support at its 10-week moving average, its first test since clearing a cup-with-handle base in October.
Fiber optic networking gear maker Finisar (FNSR) spiked 13% after a healthy fiscal Q2 report. The stock ended Thursday deep in a six-month consolidation.

Stocks started the week in a quietly positive mood Monday, grabbing quick early gains despite a weak reading on August home sales. The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq each pushed up 0.8%. The S&P 500 added 0.7%.

The stock market today rolled out in predictably soft trade, with volume down 32% on the Nasdaq and 75% lower on the NYSE vs. options expiration-inflated action on Friday. Tuesday and Wednesday may also see softer trade, with the Yom Kippur holiday beginning at sundown on Tuesday.

In economic news, existing-home sales dropped sharply in August, the National Association of Realtors said, to an annualized pace of 5.31 million. Economist consensus had expected a mild slowdown to 5.5 million from July's 5.59 million pace. A statement from the group said higher prices may be shutting out some potential buyers.
The Atlanta Federal Reserve trimmed its inflation estimate for the coming year, with its Business Inflation Expectations Index dipping to 1.7% for September vs. a 1.8% result in August.
In stocks,Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and CyberArk Software (CYBR) jumped 4% apiece on analyst upgrades.

Chipmaker Atmel (ATML) fired up a 13% advance. It announced Sunday that Germany-based Dialog Semiconductor would buy Atmel in a cash/stock deal valued at $4.6 billion. The companies expect the deal to close in Q1 of 2016. Wedbush, Topeka and FBR Capital all downgraded Atmel following the news.
Among Nasdaq 100 stocks, Tesla Motors (TSLA) and Adobe Systems (ADBE) added almost 2% each.

Lennar (LEN) topped the S&P 500 with a gain of just over 2%. The Miami-based homebuilder reported stronger-than-expected fiscal Q3 sales and earnings. The big volume gain put a bit of daylight between the stock and its 50-day moving average. Lennar is attempting to build a base beside a base after a failed breakout attempt.

On the injured list, Neogen (NEOG) was down 9% but paring losses after an opening dive. The maker of diagnostic test kits for foods, pharmaceuticals and animal vaccines reported weak fiscal first-quarter results. The loss damaged the base-building effort that followed a failed breakout attempt in late July.
Leading stocks generally opened in good standing, with effectively all of the IBD 50 list advancing from the get-go.
Cal-Maine (CALM) climbed more than 2%. The Jackson, Miss.-based egg producer is just below a 58.04 buy point in a double-bottom base.

Global Payments (GPN) also jumped more than 2%.
