Adobe Systems (ADBE) unexpectedly returned to profit growth in its fiscal Q2 as the software maker's subscription-based business continued to boom, sending shares sharply higher after the close. Adobe earned 37 cents a share excluding various items. That was 3% higher than a year earlier and the first such increase in seven quarters. Wall Street had expected another decline, to…

Adobe Systems (ADBE) is having great success getting its customer base to switch from purchased to subscription software via the Internet cloud. And it's counting on a major update to its Creative Cloud offering in the next few months to fuel even greater adoption. Late Tuesday, the creative and marketing software maker posted better-than-expected fiscal Q1 earnings and gave Q2…

Adobe Systems posted better-than-expected fiscal Q1 results late Tuesday, as the provider of creative software and online marketing services continues its transition to the Internet cloud. Its guidance also beat. Adobe Systems (ADBE) earned 30 cents a share excluding items, down 14% from the year-earlier quarter, on sales of $1 billion, down a fraction, for the quarter ended Feb. 28.…

Adobe Systems (ADBE) has been progressing ahead of plan with its business transition to the Internet cloud, and investors will be seeking more news on that front when the company reports fiscal first-quarter earnings after the market close Tuesday. Last week, at least three Wall Street analysts raised price targets on Adobe stock. And on Monday, RBC Capital Markets analyst…

Wall Street analysts have been raising their price targets on Adobe Systems (ADBE) stock ahead of the company's fiscal first-quarter report, slated for release after the market close Tuesday. Jefferies analyst Ross MacMillan on Thursday raised his target price on Adobe stock to 80 from 65 and reiterated his buy rating. On Wednesday, UBS analyst Brent Thill raised his target…

Adobe Systems (ADBE) shares jumped 4.5% in after-hours trading Tuesday after the graphic design software maker reported better-than-expected results for the start of its transition into all-cloud mode.

The San Jose, Calif.-based company earned 36 cents a share excluding items, on sales of $1.011 billion for its fiscal second quarter ended May 31. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected Adobe to earn 33 cents on sales of $1.008 billion.
Still, earnings and sales fell 40% and 10%, respectively, from the year-earlier quarter as Adobe transitions its business from licensed to subscription software.
Adobe said it ended Q2 with 700,000 paid subscribers to its Creative Cloud service, an increase of 221,000, or 46%, from the number of subscriptions as of March 1, the end of its fiscal Q1.
Adobe's Marketing Cloud business reported quarterly revenue of $229.6 million, with bookings growth of greater than 25%.

"Our Q2 results reflect our leadership position in digital media and digital marketing," Adobe CEO Shantanu Narayen said in a statement. "Creative Cloud is revolutionizing the creative process, and Adobe Marketing Cloud is quickly becoming the platform of choice for the world's leading brands, advertising agencies and media companies."

Adobe's flagship Creative business is seeing near-term declines as customers move from buying the software upfront with one-time payments to leasing the software on a monthly subscription basis. Over time, Adobe expects its customers will end up paying more for its software, because they won't be skipping regular releases to save money.
Adobe is targeting 1.25 million subscribers by fiscal year's end. It ended Q1 with 479,000 paid Creative Cloud members, up 47% from its Q4, with 153,000 net new subscribers.

On May 6, Adobe announced that it stopped development of its legacy licensed creative professional software and was putting its full support behind its Internet cloud offerings. It said new versions of such familiar products as Photoshop, Illustrator and Dreamweaver would be available only through Adobe's Creative Cloud service. Adobe also stopped shipping packaged versions of its software for sale at retail, favoring digital downloads.
"Strong Results"

"I'm pleased with the numbers. They even beat our numbers for (Creative) subscribers," Bernstein analyst Mark Moerdler told IBD. "The key metric the Street has been watching has been the additional subscriptions.
"We were at the high end (of estimates) and (Adobe) beat us. They also did very well on the digital marketing end of the business, above consensus there. So it was strong results."

Adobe has beaten every target it has set for itself so far for its Creative Cloud business, so there is no reason to doubt their ability to beat their full-year target of 1.25 million subscribers, he said. That would position them well to make their target of 4 million subscribers by 2015.
"That's the really important number," Moerdler said. "They are definitely getting momentum."
On a conference call with analysts Tuesday, Narayen said reaching 700,000 paid Creative Cloud subscribers after just a year of availability was "an amazing achievement."

Adobe is delivering new features and services at a faster pace with Creative Cloud, Narayen said. The company released its last major update in May. It includes desktop and mobile access to Web services, enhanced file sharing and collaboration and new publishing capabilities.

"Since we launched Creative Cloud, the overwhelming majority of customers buying on Adobe.com have selected Creative Cloud rather than CS6," the final version of its Creative Suite licensed product, he said. "Customer satisfaction rates are high, and the top reasons customers cite for their love of Creative Cloud include having access to everything in the product portfolio, enabling them to try new tools and build new skills; always being up-to-date with latest features and capabilities; and the affordable monthly membership fee.
"These benefits are compelling to our existing customer base and are helping us achieve our goal of bringing in new customers."

Narayen admitted that Adobe's decision to discontinue perpetual licensing of new versions of its desktop products "has caused concern with some customers." He said the company is listening to feedback from customers and is evaluating additional options to help users with the transition to the Internet cloud offerings.Adobe Systems (ADBE) shares jumped 4.5% in after-hours trading Tuesday after the graphic design software maker reported better-than-expected results for the start of its transition into all-cloud mode.The San Jose, Calif.-based company earned 36 cents a share excluding items, on sales of $1.011 billion for its fiscal second quarter ended May 31. In its first quarterly report since announcing plans to go all in on the Internet cloud, Adobe Systems (ADBE) is expected to show a continued slide in sales and earnings as it makes the transition from licensed to subscription software.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the graphic design software firm to earn 33 cents a share excluding items on sales of nearly $1.01 billion for its fiscal second quarter. That would translate to year-to-year declines of 45% and 10%, respectively. Adobe is scheduled to report Q2 results after the market close on Tuesday.

Adobe's flagship Creative Suite business is seeing near-term declines as customers move from buying the software upfront with one-time payments to leasing the software on a monthly subscription basis. Over time, Adobe expects its customers will end up paying more for its software, because they won't be skipping incremental releases to save money.

Investors watching the Q2 results will be focused on the company's transition to the subscription business model. Key metrics include subscriber numbers and annual revenue run rate. Adobe is targeting 1.25 million subscribers by year's end. As of March 19, Adobe had more than 500,000 paid subscribers of its Creative Cloud offering.
Adobe added 153,000 net new subscribers for the Creative Cloud in its fiscal Q1 ended March 1. It ended Q1 with 479,000 paid Creative Cloud members, up 47% from its Q4.
RBC Capital Markets analyst Robert Breza expects Adobe to added 200,000 new Creative Cloud subscribers in Q2. Adobe guided to "slightly more" than the 153,000 subscribers it added in Q1.

"As a reminder, subscribers are expected to increase (quarter-to-quarter) through the year and total 1.25M for the year," Breza wrote in a research note Thursday. "The recent launch of Creative Cloud for Teams and a yet to be launched enterprise version, which together represent (about) 50% of the installed base, should help ramp subscribers going forward."

On May 6, Adobe announced that it has stopped development of its legacy licensed creative professional software and is putting its full support behind its Internet cloud offerings. New versions of such familiar products as Photoshop, Illustrator and Dreamweaver would be available only through Adobe's Creative Cloud service.
That announcement has helped to accelerate adoption of Adobe's subscription offering, Wedge Partners analyst Kirk Adams said in a research note Thursday.

For its current fiscal Q3, Wall Street analysts are modeling Adobe to earn 35 cents a share minus items on sales of $1.01 billion. Those targets would translate to year-to-year declines of 40% and 6%, respectively.

Stocks were trading slightly lower as the noon hour approached Wednesday, with the markets waiting to hear from the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee.

The policymaking committee concludes a two-day meeting with an announcement expected at 2 p.m. ET, followed by a press conference with Fed Chair Janet Yellen. The Fed is expected to leave interest rates near zero and to continue to wind down its bond-buying program. Investors will be parsing the Fed's statement for clues regarding its view of economic growth.
In the stock market today, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 were off 0.1%, and the Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.2%. Volume was running higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.
FedEx (FDX) jumped nearly 5% after reporting better-than-expected earnings.
Adobe Systems (ADBE) gapped up and was trading nearly 8% higher, also after a good earnings report.
Among IBD 50 stocks, 23 were up and 27 were down. The best performer was Irish drugmaker Shire (SHPG), up 3% to an all-time high. The stock broke out of a base Monday.

The worst performer was Alliance Fiber Optic (AFOP), which dropped nearly 7% and pierced its 50-day moving in above-average volume.Stocks were trading slightly lower as the noon hour approached Wednesday, with the markets waiting to hear from the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee.The policymaking committee concludes a two-day meeting with an announcement expected at 2 p.m. ET, followed by a press conference with Fed Chair Janet Yellen. The Fed is expected to leave interest rates near zero and to continue to wind down its bond-buying program. The stock broke out of a base Monday.The worst performer was Alliance Fiber Optic (AFOP), which dropped nearly 7% and pierced its 50-day moving in above-average volume.
Stock futures were positive, but not by much, ahead of Wednesday's open.
Dow futures held 2.5 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were ahead 4.2 points. S&P 500 futures clung to a 0.2% advance. Small caps lagged, with the Russell 2000 index down 4.1 points.

The stock market today will be all ears as the Federal Open Market Committee wraps up its two-day meeting with a policy announcement this afternoon. The consensus appears to expect further tapering, but no change to the target interest rate.

The day's other economic news was relatively thin. The current account deficit expanded to $111.2 billion in the first quarter, vs. a revised $87.3 billion deficit for the fourth quarter. The balance, a measure of transactions between the U.S. and all other countries, rose to 2.6% of GDP, vs. 2% in Q4.
Some heavyweight headlines did little to stir stocks in premarket trade.

Amazon.com (AMZN) rose less than 1% ahead of a press event scheduled in Seattle today, during which the company is expected to introduce a smartphone, in a partnership with AT&T (T). AT&T shares were up a fraction before the open. Amazon has been scooping through a 30% deep consolidation since January.

German chemicals and pharmaceutical giant Bayer (BAYRY) was flat after reports that it had signed a $14.2 billion loan to acquire the consumer care business of New Jersey-based Merck (MRK). Merck shares were also unmoved.

Adobe Systems (ADBE) bolted 9% higher after a surprise increase in its fiscal second quarter earnings. The maker of software programs including Photoshop, Acrobat and Reader ended Tuesday 5% below the 71.21 buy point of a four-month cup base.

Furniture maker La-Z-Boy (LZB) dropped 9% after narrowly topping fiscal fourth-quarter earnings expectations but stopping short of estimates on the revenue line. The stock has been unable to climb above key levels of support to start the right side of a five-month base.

Overseas, China's markets finished lower for a second day. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained, still working to take back ground lost during Monday's session, despite data showing a sharp drop in exports in May. In Europe, stocks were narrowly higher at midday.

The dollar eased against the euro, strengthened vs. the yen. Oil continued to bob between $106 and $107 a barrel. Natural gas was firm at $4.75 per million British thermal units. Stocks meandered ahead of the Federal Reserve's announcement on monetary policy, expected at 2 p.m. ET, as volume remained lower on both major exchanges.

Fed announcements typically roil the markets for an hour or two, until investors absorb whatever news emerges. The Fed's open market committee is expected to keep interest rates near zero and continue to wind down its bond-buying program.
Chairwoman Janet Yellen will hold a 2:30 p.m. ET press conference.
The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average were both down 0.1%. The S&P 500 was up a smidgen.

In the stock market today, FedEx (FDX) and Adobe Systems (ADBE) reported better-than-expected earnings and gapped up to all-time highs. FedEx broke out of a cup-with-handle base and was up 5%. Adobe was up 8% and was at an all-time high.
Amazon (AMZN) was set to announce its a smartphone, said to have 3D capabilities. It was up less than 1% in below-average volume as it works on a long consolidation.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) took its $53 billion bid for Botox-maker Allergan (AGN) directly to shareholders by launching a tender offer. Valeant was trading little changed just below its 200-day moving average as it tries to rise off the lows of a base. Stocks churned out a mixed open Wednesday as earnings reports fueled some significant early moves.
The Nasdaq slipped 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.1%. The S&P 500 hung on to a fractional gain.

Investor attention on the stock market today was focused largely on the policy announcement expected from the Fed at 2 p.m. ET. Volume picked up ahead of the announcement, rising 16% on the Nasdaq and 12% on the NYSE compared with the same time Tuesday.

In stocks,Adobe Systems (ADBE) gapped up 9%, leading both the Nasdaq 100 and the S&P 500, after reporting better-than-expected results for its May-ended quarter late Tuesday. The stock cleared a 15-week pattern.

Industrial gas supplier Air Products & Chemicals (APD) popped 7% to a new high after confirming that it had hired Seifi Ghasemi, chief executive of Rockwood Holdings (ROC), to replace current CEO John McGlade, effective July 1. Air Products broke out of a flat base with a buy point of 124.50.

FedEx (FDX) delivered a 5% gain at the start of trade after fiscal fourth-quarter sales and earnings comfortably topped expectations. The stock broke out of a shallow cup-with-handle base with a 145.09 buy point.
Exxon Mobil (XOM) rose a fraction and oil prices showed no response to reports that Exxon had evacuated its employees from the oil-production region in southern Iraq.
Leading stocks managed a healthy start, with more IBD 50 stocks rising than falling as trade began Wednesday.
Shire (SHPG) rattled off a 2% gain to mark a new high in solid trade. The Ireland-based drugmaker is extended after a breakout Monday.

Another Irish drug firm, Actavis (ACT), added almost 2%. The stock broke out of a shallow cup-with-handle base with a 145.09 buy point.Exxon Mobil (XOM) rose a fraction and oil prices showed no response to reports that Exxon had evacuated its employees from the oil-production region in southern Iraq.Leading stocks managed a healthy start, with more IBD 50 stocks rising than falling as trade began Wednesday.Shire (SHPG) rattled off a 2% gain to mark a new high in solid trade. The Ireland-based drugmaker is extended after a breakout Monday.Another Irish drug firm, Actavis (ACT), added almost 2%. That was enough to hoist shares just above a 216.80 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Stocks finished up for the day as a bit of volume came into the market late.The Nasdaq finished up 0.4%; the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2%. Volume was higher on both exchanges, according to preliminary data.In the stock market today, Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) spiked in the final minute of trading, vaulting as much as 13% before giving back part of the loss. As much as 600,000 shares, nearly as much as its average daily volume, traded in the final minute. The stock gave back more gains in after-hours trading. There was no news reported.Adobe Systems (ADBE) traded flat but was up sharply after hours. The company reported Q2 earnings of 37 cents a share vs. a consensus estimate of 30 cents. Revenue was slightly above estimates. Adobe ended the quarter with 2.3 million paid subscribers for its Creative Cloud service, 464,000 more than Q1.GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH) soared 16% in nearly quadruple normal trade but was down after hours. On Monday, the company announced that the FDA had given fast-track status to Epidiolex, its drug for the treatment of Dravet syndrome, and its stock was up 16%. After the close Tuesday, the company announced an offering of 1.7 million shares.The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee completes a two-day meeting Wednesday. The Fed has been systematically winding down its bond-buying program. Investors will be parsing the statement issued at the conclusion of the meeting and at the press conference scheduled by Chair Janet Yellen.Netflix (NFLX) and Expedia (EXPE) were among Tuesday's best-performing stocks. Both received favorable analyst comments.

Wall Street rose for a second day Tuesday, leaving the major indexes just below record highs, as higher oil prices boosted energy stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%, the Nasdaq climbed 0.4% and the S&P 500 ended up 0.3%, with the latter two finishing just 1% below their all-time peaks. Volume was about 10% higher on both the NYSE and Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.

In the stock market today, oil producer Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) and driller Diamond Offshore (DO) each rose 6%, leading the S&P 500. Oil prices jumped more than 3% to just below $48 a barrel amid a strike by oil workers in Brazil and a port shutdown in Libya.

Noah Holdings (NOAH) led the IBD 50, jumping 10% in heavy volume as it climbs the right side of a deep base. The provider of wealth management services in China is due to report Q3 results Nov. 16. Profit for the period is seen rising 21% to 41 cents a share, which would be the biggest gain in four quarters.
Medical products stock Cambrex (CBM) rose more than 6% after a better-than-expected Q3 earnings report. It's also climbing the right side of a new base.

In post-session trading, luxury electric vehicle maker Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose sharply on a narrower-than-expected Q3 loss. The stock fell more than 2% during the regular session, ending 27% off its 52-week high.
Shares of real estate website Zillow (Z) was down about 5% after hours following its Q3 results.

Also after the close, Groupon (GPN) edged higher after its Q3 report. The provider of discounts from retailers also announced that COO Rich Williams will replace Eric Lefkofsky as CEO. Lefkofsky will become chairman.
LGI Homes (LGIH), Facebook (FB), Epam Systems (EPAM) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) are among companies reporting quarterly earnings Wednesday.

Microsoft on Tuesday unveiled its third-generation Surface tablet, a device it hopes will sell as a replacement for notebook computers.While tablets have been billed for a few years as laptop PC replacements, the truth is that most tablet owners still use notebooks as well, Panos Panay, corporate vice president of Microsoft (MSFT) Surface, said at a press event in New York City.Usability trade-offs have kept tablets from replacing notebooks, he said. Panay noted how 96% of Apple (AAPL) iPad owners also own notebook computers.The new Surface Pro 3 tablet features a bigger screen, an improved attachable keyboard and a digital pen for making handwritten notes and drawings on screen.The new tablet will be available for pre-order on Wednesday starting at $799. The optional Surface Pro Type cover costs $129.99. The Surface Pro 3 will be in stores on June 20 in the U.S. and Canada, the company said.Microsoft needed to try something different to compete against tablet leaders Apple and Samsung, FBR Capital Markets analyst Daniel Ives said.Positioning the Surface Pro 3 as a laptop replacement "gives Microsoft a more unique selling feature than being another 'me too' tablet product," Ives said. "Strategically they are definitely taking a different direction."Because the third-generation Surface Pro, with keyboard cover, costs $830 at a minimum, Microsoft has to position the device against high-end laptops like Apple's MacBook Air, Gartner analyst Mike Silver said.He points out that Microsoft's two earlier Pro tablets also were pitched as laptop replacements. But the tech giant is now "being bolder about how they communicate that," Silver said.Microsoft appears to be targeting enterprise and business users with the Surface Pro 3. At the press event, the company showed usage scenarios for architects and creative professionals.Buyers Include BMW, CokeCompanies such as BMW Group and Coca-Cola (KO) have already committed to purchasing and deploying the device inside their organizations, Microsoft said.Microsoft also is selling a desktop docking station and keyboard that costs $199.99 and targets office workers.The Surface Pro 3 runs on fourth-generation Intel (INTC) Core processors. The tablet is 0.36-inch thin and weighs 1.76 pounds. It boasts up to nine hours of Web-browsing battery life.The basic model comes with 4 gigabytes of RAM, 64 GB of flash storage and Intel's Core i3 processor. Microsoft is selling five configurations of the Surface Pro 3. The top-of-the-line model costs $1,949 and comes with 8 GB of RAM, 512 GB of storage and Intel's i7 chip.Like its predecessors, the Surface Pro 3 can double as a tablet and notebook. It features a more rigid dockable keyboard and adjustable screen kickstand that will allow for laptop typing, something that was difficult with earlier models.The keyboard's trackpad was enlarged and improved as well.Plus, the device features a special pen for writing digital ink on documents, editing photos and other tasks where pen input is preferable.The Surface Pro 3 has a 12-inch screen; the previous model had a 10.6-inch display. The new screen is 38% bigger than Surface Pro 2, with 50% more pixels."Ladies and gentlemen, this is the tablet that can replace your laptop — the Surface Pro 3," Panay said as he held up the ultrathin, lightweight device.A key application of the new tablet is to replace an analog pen and notepad. Clicking the top of the special pen commands the Surface tablet to turn on with a OneNote writing surface displayed.Click the Surface Pen again, and the note is synced to the Internet cloud via Microsoft's OneDrive.The software leader's executives also demonstrated using the pen to do a New York Times crossword puzzle app and to edit images in Adobe Systems' (ADBE) Photoshop.Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella spoke at the press event about how Surface hardware is part of the company's "mobile first, cloud first" strategy.Microsoft released its first-generation Surface tablets in October 2012. The first Pro configuration came out in February 2013.Microsoft came out with its second generation Surface tablets in October 2013."They're hoping the third time will be the charm," Ives said.The first two waves of Surface tablets barely put a dent in the tablet market, which is dominated by Apple's iPad and Google (GOOGL) Android-based devices.Not discussed at Tuesday's press event were any new consumer Surface RT tablets or a rumored mini tablet.

Adobe Systems (ADBE) signed up more subscribers than expected to its Creative Cloud service last quarter. That news late Thursday cheered investors, who pushed Adobe stock up 7% in after-hours trading.

The graphic design and media software maker posted sales and earnings for its fiscal Q4 ended Nov. 29 that met views, but it gave Q1 and full-year guidance well below views. Wall Street, though, keyed in on the growth of the company's cloud-computing business.
Adobe ended its Q4 with 1.44 million paid Creative Cloud subscriptions, up 402,000, or 39%, from Q3. It said enterprise adoption of the service was stronger than expected.

"In addition to paid members, we currently have millions of customers in the pipeline who are trying out the service," Adobe CEO Shantanu Narayen said on a conference call with analysts. Adobe is targeting 3 million Creative Cloud subscriptions by the end of 2014 and 4 million by the end of 2015.
"Creative Cloud members are receiving a constant stream of new features, products and services each month, and customer satisfaction is high based on our surveys," Narayen said.

Morningstar analyst Norman Young said Adobe's target for Creative Cloud subscribers by the end of 2015 might be conservative. That number is based on active buyers of its licensed software product. There could be 8 million more customers using older versions of Adobe's software, Young told IBD.

Adobe earned 32 cents a share excluding items for Q4. Sales were $1.04 billion, above the $1.03 billion expected by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. That translates to year-to-year declines of 48% in earnings and 10% in sales.

The move to a cloud business model holds the promise of higher lifetime revenue per customer, as users switch to paying a monthly subscription fee rather than buying software products outright and using them indefinitely. But the company's top and bottom lines will take a short-term hit as customers stop paying up front for software.
For fiscal Q1, Adobe expects EPS ex items of 25 cents on sales of $975 million, based on the midpoint of its guidance. Analysts were expecting 34 cents and $1.02 billion.
For fiscal 2014, Adobe guided to $4.06 billion in sales, flat with 2013, and EPS of $1.10. That's well off the $5.12 billion and $2.28 analysts have been targeting.
Missing Views Is ... Good

In recent quarters, when Adobe's results come in short of Wall Street estimates, that's good, Wedge Partners analyst Kirk Adams said in a research note. "That means that the subscription business continues to overtake the perpetual business faster than expectations," he said. "Adobe has done a wonderful job transitioning a 30-year-old software company into one of the most intriguing and exciting stories in the technology sector today."
Adobe's Creative Cloud business now has annualized recurring revenue of $768 million. Total digital media annualized recurring revenue rose to $911 million.

"We are leading the software industry in transitioning our business to the cloud, which is enabling us to target higher top-line growth and greater recurring revenue," Adobe CFO Mark Garrett said in a statement. "We are raising our long-term revenue growth targets, with a compound annual revenue growth rate of 20% between fiscal year 2014 and fiscal year 2016."
Adobe is growing its cloud business faster than many analysts had expected.

Adobe has two main businesses: its Creative Cloud, which includes products like Photoshop and Illustrator, and Marketing Cloud, which helps marketers manage and optimize their online advertising and promotional campaigns.
Adobe's digital marketing business achieved 38% year-over-year revenue growth in Q4. Adobe Marketing Cloud achieved $1.02 billion in annual revenue in 2013, up 26%.

"We continue to have the most comprehensive offering in the market for chief marketing officers, chief revenue officers, advertising agencies, publishing executives and digital marketers," Narayen said.

Adobe, he said, is moving from a software business growing 3% to 5% a year to one with 20% compound annual growth over the next three years.Adobe Systems (ADBE) signed up more subscribers than expected to its Creative Cloud service last quarter. When Adobe Systems (ADBE) posts fiscal first-quarter results after the market close Tuesday, Wall Street will be looking for continued progress in the company's shift from licensed software to subscription services.

Adobe is transitioning its business from upfront sales of its software for creative professionals to recurring, monthly subscriber fees. Last quarter, the San Jose, Calif.-based company said the transition has been occurring faster than expected, pinching near-term results but improving its long-term outlook.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Adobe to earn 31 cents a share excluding items, on sales of $986 million. If it meets those targets, EPS and sales will fall 46% and 6%, respectively, year over year.
For the current Q2, Wall Street expects Adobe to earn 34 cents a share, down 43%, on sales of nearly $1.02 billion, down 10%.

Baird analyst Steven Ashley expects Adobe to meet the Street's Q1 forecast, based on his firm's survey of creative professionals. On the plus side, hiring activity in the creative professional industry is picking up, boding well for sales of Adobe's graphic design software, he said in a March 12 research note.

A "key metric" for Adobe is subscriber growth, which appears to be coming in waves, Ashley says. Initial growth came from small creative agencies, followed late last year by public sector and higher education buyers. Midsize corporations should provide a boost to Q1 results and beyond. And enterprise subscriptions will pick up later this year, he says.

Adobe expects the bulk of its customers to transition to Internet cloud-based software by the end of 2015. By then, it forecasts having about 4 million individual and team Creative Cloud paid subscriptions. Creative Cloud includes all of Adobe's familiar creative professional software products including Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign and Dreamweaver.

In midday trading Monday, Adobe shares were down a fraction. Stock futures muscled higher ahead of Friday's open, aiming to build on what is playing out to be a strong week. Dow futures were 92.3 points above fair market value and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures were up 19 points. S&P 500 futures climbed 7.9 points.

The stock market today sets out with the Nasdaq sitting on a 3% gain for the week, the S&P 500 up 2.9%. The S&P 500 is back above its 50-day moving average. The Nasdaq opens nearly 4% above its 50-day line. Whether the indexes can hold the psychologically important 50-day lines of support while weighed down with a heavy load of distribution days, will be a key factor in the current rally.
The economic calendar was relatively quiet. The Kansas City Federal Reserve's regional manufacturing survey is due out at 11 a.m. ET.

St. Louis Federal Reserve President James Bullard and New York Federal Reserve President William Dudley are scheduled to speak this morning. U.S. crude futures continued to struggle, trading down more than 1% and about flat for the week, at just below $40 a barrel. Prices may see some effect from results of the weekly rig count from Baker Hughes (BHI) at 1 p.m.
Nike (NKE) hoisted the Dow with a 4% gain. It announced late Thursday a $12 billion, four-year share buyback program, on top of the current $8 billion buyback, to be completed by the end of 2016.

Management also increased the quarterly dividend 14% to 32 cents and announced a 2-for-1 stock split, effective after the Dec. 23 market close. The IBD 50 stock ended Thursday in a test of support at its 50-day moving average, 4% above a 117.82 cup-base buy point.
Retail industry groups, which have taken a serious beating over the past two weeks, continued to make splashy moves.
Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) spiraled 18% higher after earnings soared past consensus expectations and revenue fell less than forecast.

Ross Stores (ROST) surged 7%. The Dublin, Calif.-based chain reported solid third-quarter results after Thursday's close. The stock closed Thursday 6% above its Nov. 13 low, and 18% below its Aug. 18 high after a double-dip consolidation.

Foot Locker (FL) hopped up 7% after its Q3 sales and earnings cleared analyst expectations. The shoe retailer, with close ties to Nike, finished Thursday up 6% this week, and 20% below its September high.
Williams-Sonoma (WSM) slipped nearly 4% after beating Q3 sales and earnings expectations, but guiding Q4 results below estimates.

Intuit (INTU) rallied nearly 9% before the open. The developer of Quickbooks and TurboTax reported after Thursday's close a fiscal Q1 profit of 9 cents per share, vs. consensus projections for a per-share loss of 4 cents. Revenue growth of 17% trounced expectations and management raised its Q2 EPS guidance above estimates. Shares ended Thursday below a 100.73 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Among the morning's heaviest losses, Mentor Graphics (MENT) unspooled 27% after reporting late Thursday its Q3 revenue and earnings were a shade shy of consensus views. The kicker was Q4 earnings, which management said would come in at less than half of current consensus projections. The developer of automated design software finished Thursday's session just above a 27.48 cup base buy point.Stock futures muscled higher ahead of Friday's open, aiming to build on what is playing out to be a strong week. Adobe Systems (ADBE) continued to commandeer the top, Anadarko Petroleum (APC) the bottom, of the S&P 500 stocks. Home Depot (HD) led the Dow with a 1% gain. Adobe's 11% gain also topped the Nasdaq 100.

Video-game maker Electronic Arts (EA) muscled up 6% in heavy trade, climbing off recent lows but meeting resistance at its 50-day moving average. The Redwood City, Calif.-based company began correcting decisively in mid-November, after problems began cropping up following the release of "Battlefield 4," the latest revision of its blockbuster game franchise.

Among leaders, Qiwi (QIWI) was up 8% and stretching its lead among IBD 50 stocks. The gain left the Cypress-based provider of online payment solutions to Russia's Internet more than 5% above a 50.75 buy point in an ascending base.

Losses were generally mild among leaders. At the bottom of the IBD 50 list, Biogen Idec (BIIB) showed a 2% decline. The mild-volume slip put shares 9% below a Dec. 2 high.Stocks clung to thin gains in weak trade near midday Friday.The Nasdaq narrowed its increase to 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average was steady with a 0.1% gain. The S&P 500 struggled to keep its fractional advance.Volume continued to soften on the stock market today, down 17% on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared to trade at the same time Thursday.Adobe Systems (ADBE) continued to commandeer the top, Anadarko Petroleum (APC) the bottom, of the S&P 500 stocks. Home Depot (HD) led the Dow with a 1% gain. Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq held on to its 0.5% advance.
Volume was soft, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 90% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today is rebounding, but still correcting, with both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 deep in the hole for the week. The market received an early assist today from China, where some rule changes and federally engineered buying helped lift markets to their first healthy close of the week.
December hiring in the U.S. was also a factor, as the Labor Department reported payrolls jumped by 292,000 during the month — far above expectations.
Wholesale inventories dropped 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said. That was even with October's slip and below expectations for no change.

The market will have an ear out for post-payroll comments from San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams, who speaks at 11:30 a.m. ET, and from Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker, on the docket for a 1 p.m. speech.
Apple (AAPL) and DuPont (DD) raced to the head of the Dow, up nearly 2% each. Wynn Resorts (WYNN)headed the S&P 500 with a 4% gain.
Gap (GPS) cratered 7% after announcing late Thursday its December same-store sales slipped 5% vs. consensus views for a 3.5% decline.

Chipmaker and Apple supplier Qorvo (QRVO) dropped 4%. The Greensboro, N.C. company late Thursday lowered its Q3 revenue guidance to well below consensus expectations. The company also said it repurchased $250 million in shares during the quarter, leaving $750 million in its share repurchase program and a cash balance of more than $1 billion. Shares traded down 14% for the week and 50% below a June high.

On the IBD 50 list, Universal Display (OLED) flashed ahead nearly 5% at the open. The maker of organic light emitting diode chips used in high definition TV and computer screens is trading below a 55.93 buy point in a cup base. It triggered an automatic sell signal by diving more than 8% below that mark.

Hawaiian (HA) jumped more than 3% after reporting its total numbers of passengers rose 4.1% and its load factor crept up to 82.9% in the fourth quarter. The stock remains well below its 50-day moving average and is attempting to build the right side of a 22% deep consolidation.

Aircraft carrier mechanic Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) sailed ahead nearly 4%. Cowen & Co. upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Graphic design software maker Adobe Systems (ADBE) late Thursday posted better-than-expected fiscal Q4 results, as it continues to make progress in moving customers to its Internet cloud-based offerings. The San Jose, Calif.-based company earned 61 cents a share excluding items, on sales of $1.15 billion, for the quarter ended Nov. 30. That translates to a year-over-year earnings decline of 9%…

When it comes to Adobe Systems'  (ADBE) 2013 guidance, less is more. The graphic design software company late Thursday delivered better-than-expected fiscal fourth-quarter results, but forecast 2013 sales and earnings well below Wall Street's targets. Here was IBD's story. But investors were OK with that Friday, since Adobe's transition from a licensed software business to a subscription model will…
Adobe Systems (ADBE) shares on Wednesday climbed to their highest level since April 2010, a day ahead of company's fiscal fourth-quarter earnings report.
In midday trading Wednesday, Adobe shares were up 1.7%, near 36.15. Earlier in the session, the stock hit 36.22, its highest level in more than 30 months.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the graphic design software maker to earn 57 cents a share excluding items, on sales of $1.1 billion, in the November quarter. That would represent year-over-year declines of 15% and 4%, respectively.
For the February quarter, analysts are targeting Adobe to earn 56 cents a share minus items, on sales of $1.07 billion. That would be a 2% decline in earnings, on a sales increase of 2%.

On Tuesday, Adobe released figures showing what it described as "huge customer momentum" for its Creative Cloud offering. The San Jose, Calif.-based company has more than 1 million free and paid memberships for its online software, including about 326,000 paid individual members.

Adobe is attempting to transition its business from licensed software, where users pay upfront for its software and use it indefinitely, to a subscription model where customers pay for the software on a monthly basis.

Pacific Crest analyst Brendan Barnicle said results appear mixed for Adobe's Creative Cloud so far. He says resellers in the U.S. and Europe have told him that packaged versions of Creative Suite 6 are selling well and that many customers aren't ready yet for the pricing model associated with Adobe's Internet cloud-based offering.

In a research note Sunday, Barnicle said Adobe's transition to a cloud model will be rocky and that Wall Street's estimates for Adobe's fiscal 2013 earnings per share will "need to come down dramatically."
Cowen and Co. analyst Peter Goldmacher says Adobe is showing solid progress in its transition to a subscription business model.

"Adobe has commented that the move to subscriptions is happening faster than it had first modeled, and emboldened by its initial success, is investing aggressively to accelerate the transition," Goldmacher said in a research note Monday. "Given that the lifetime value of a customer in the subs model is on average 20% greater than the shrink-wrapped model, we believe this is a prudent decision."

Adobe Systems (ADBE) late Tuesday missed Wall Street targets for fiscal Q3, but results were hurt by the company's faster-than-expected transition to an Internet cloud-based business.
Adobe ended the August quarter with 1.03 million paid subscribers to its Creative Cloud business, an increase of 331,000 subscribers and up 47% over the fiscal Q2 total.
"We exceeded 1 million subscriptions during Q3, demonstrating that the transition to Creative Cloud is happening sooner than expected," Adobe CEO Shantanu Narayen said in a statement.
Adobe shares were up 5.5% in after-hours trading Tuesday, after it released the results.

The move to software accessed via the Internet "cloud" holds the promise of higher lifetime revenue per customer, as users switch to a monthly subscription fee rather than buying software products outright and using them indefinitely. But the company's top and bottom lines will take a short-term hit as customers stop buying perpetual license software, executives say.

"Our customers are overwhelmingly choosing subscriptions instead of perpetual model licenses, which is accelerating our business model transition," Adobe Chief Financial Officer Mark Garrett said. "During Q3, 41% of our revenue was recurring and we exited the quarter with record deferred revenue on our balance sheet. These results are building a stronger, more predictable revenue model for Adobe, which will drive higher long-term growth."

The San Jose, Calif.-based maker of design and marketing software earned 32 cents a share minus items in the quarter ended Aug. 30. That's down 45% from the year-earlier quarter and 2 cents lower than analysts expected. Sales dipped 8% to $995 million, shy of Wall Street's target of $1.01 billion.
The Q3 results marked the fourth quarter in a row that Adobe's earnings per share have fallen on a year-to-year basis and third straight quarter of declining sales.

The declines are expected to continue in the current quarter. Adobe guided analysts to Q4 earnings of 31 cents a share minus items, on sales of $1.025 billion, at the midpoint of its guidance. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had been targeting EPS ex items of 41 cents on sales of $1.08 billion.

Adobe has two primary businesses: its Creative Cloud, which includes products like Photoshop and Illustrator, and Marketing Cloud, which helps marketers manage and optimize their online ad and promotional campaigns.
Investors have backed Adobe's transition to the cloud. Its stock hit an all-time high Monday of 48.70, and closed Tuesday's regular session even, at 48.14.
Adobe expects to add slightly more Creative Cloud subscribers in Q4 vs. Q3. New subscriptions will be driven by enterprise agreements.
Annualized recurring revenue from Adobe's digital media business reached $655 million in Q3. It expects to reach $875 million exiting Q4, topping its prior forecast for $800 million.

Q3 revenue for the Marketing Cloud business rose 28% to $254.9 million. Adobe expects a 35% hike this quarter. The Q3 and Q4 figures include Adobe's recent acquisition of Neolane, which it's rebranded Adobe Campaign.

Also Tuesday, Adobe announced two new products for its Creative Cloud, to be available in the first half of 2014. They are its cloud pen, Project Mighty, and digital ruler, Project Napoleon. It had labeled both as "technology explorations" previously. They are meant for designers and artists to use with tablets such as Apple's (AAPL) iPad.Adobe Systems (ADBE) late Tuesday missed Wall Street targets for fiscal Q3, but results were hurt by the company's faster-than-expected transition to an Internet cloud-based business.Adobe ended the August quarter with 1.03 million paid subscribers to its Creative Cloud business, an increase of 331,000 subscribers and up 47% over the fiscal Q2 total."We exceeded 1 million subscriptions during Q3, demonstrating that the transition to Creative Cloud is happening sooner than expected," Adobe CEO Shantanu Narayen said in a statement.Adobe shares were up 5.5% in after-hours trading Tuesday, after it released the results.The move to software accessed via the Internet "cloud" holds the promise of higher lifetime revenue per customer, as users switch to a monthly subscription fee rather than buying software products outright and using them indefinitely. Stocks notched uneven early gains Tuesday as investors weighed solid new home sales and mixed durable goods data against the potential for a deal between Greece and its eurozone creditors.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. The Nasdaq added less than 0.1%. The S&P 500 split the difference, up 0.2%.
Volume was mixed on the stock market today, up 5% on the Nasdaq and 8% lower on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Monday.

The top-line number in the Commerce Department's May durable goods report showed a 1.8% decline and a downward revision to April's number to minus 1.5%. Economists had forecast a more mild 0.6% slip. The bulk of the miss was apparently due to a sharp decline in aircraft orders during the month. Minus transportation, durable goods orders rose 0.5% — in line with expectations. So far this year, durable goods orders are running 2.2% below last year's January to May period.

Housing prices improved steadily in May, lifting the Federal Housing Finance Agency's House Price Index 0.3%. That increase was equal to March's increase but just below consensus forecasts for a 0.4% gain. Year over year, the index is up 5.3%.

New home sales popped in May to an annualized rate of 546,000, according to the Commerce Department. That was up from April's (upwardly revised) 534,000 pace, well above consensus expectations of 525,000 and the strongest number since Feb. 2008.

A bit less rosy was the preliminary June manufacturing estimate from researcher Markit. Its Purchasing Managers Manufacturing Index was at 53.4, down from May's 53.8 number and below forecasts for an increase to 54.2. The number points to a third month of slowing activity and is the gauge's weakest gain in 18 months.
In stocks, it was a good morning for Florida-based companies.

Darden Restaurants (DRI) rose 3% to lead the S&P 500 by a wide margin. The Orlando-based owner of the Olive Garden, Red Lobster and other chains reported healthy fiscal fourth-quarter results and announced plans to slice off a portion of its real estate assets into a separate real estate investment trust. The stock popped to a new high, paring some gains but holding just above a cup-base buy point of 70.48.

Citrix Systems (CTXS) pecked out a 2% gain, the best increase among Nasdaq 100 stocks. The Fort Lauderdale-headquartered software developer is still in buying range, 4% above a 69.33 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.
Among leaders, most of the IBD 50 list posted modest gains and losses — with a couple of dramatic exceptions.

Ambarella (AMBA) led the list with a 9% rebound. The stock tumbled 21% Monday, following a short-seller's report on Friday that questioned the stock's valuation. The stock remains extended after a mid-May rebound from 10-week support and is well above its 10-week moving average.

At the bottom of the group, burger joint Sonic (SONC) dived 11% in massive trade. Fiscal third quarter sales and profits met consensus expectations, but full-year earnings guidance didn't. The transition also is forcing Wall Street analysts to adjust how they evaluate the health of Adobe's business, Adobe Chief Financial Officer Mark Garrett told IBD. With traditional,…

Shares of Adobe Systems (ADBE) fell in after-hours trading Wednesday after the software maker's guidance missed expectations. Adobe's fiscal Q3 report, issued after the close Wednesday, was basically in line with views, though sales were a bit light. Revenue rose 6.6% over the year-ago quarter to $1.08 billion, slightly below analysts' consensus of $1.1 billion. Profit, excluding one-time items, gained…
Stocks extended losses Thursday in choppy trading amid mixed retailer sales and jobs data.
After the close, Restoration Hardware (RH) and Adobe Systems (ADBE) were active after reporting quarterly results. Chip designer ARM Holdings (ARMH) also drew interest.

Luxury-furnishings retailer Restoration Hardware tumbled 11%, as news that co-CEO Carlos Alberini's is leaving overshadowed better-than-expected Q3 results. Profit surged to 32 cents a share from 7 cents in the year-ago period. Sales jumped 39% to $395.8 million. The company also raised its full-year profit outlook.

Adobe rose 5% in extended trading after initially trading lower. The software giant delivered fiscal Q4 earnings of 32 cents a share, down from 61 cents in the year-ago period. But that matched expectations. Sales eased to $1.04 billion vs. views of $1.03 billion. Adobe guided fiscal Q1 results below views.
ARM Holdings (ARMH) rose 1% after hours. A Bloomberg report noted that Google (GOOG) is mulling designing its own server processing using ARM's technology.

In the regular session, the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 fell 0.7% and 0.4%, respectively. The Nasdaq lost a milder 0.1%. According preliminary data, volume was mixed in the stock market today. NYSE trade edged up, while Nasdaq volume fell.

Former leader Lululemon Athletica (LULU) ran into more trouble as institutional selling in the stock continued. Shares plummeted 12% to a near six-month low, after the company reported tepid earnings and offered weak fiscal fourth-quarter guidance.

Facebook (FB) popped 5% and closed back above the 50 level in hefty trade. The stock hit a one-month high in reaction to late Wednesday's news that it's being added to the S&P 500. The social networking giant is replacing chip gear maker Teradyne (TER). Facebook continues to work on the right side of a possible base.

Stock futures pointed sharply higher ahead of Thursday's open, as the dollar fell and overseas markets showed firm gains. Dow futures were up 122 points, slightly below their earlier highs. S&P 500 futures held a 16-point gain and Nasdaq 100 futures were 26.25 points ahead. A large portion of action on the stock market today will be in response to…

Adobe Systems (ADBE) is among the software makers testing the market for selling at least some products by subscription rather than long-term license. Adobe on Monday released the latest version of its flagship Creative Suite product — Creative Suite 6 — which includes a Web-based version — Adobe Creative Cloud. CS6 will be available as a subscription service for $49.99…

Shares of Adobe Systems (ADBE) were down 3.7% in midday trading Wednesday, after being down as much as 7.6% earlier, following the graphic design software company's disclosure late Tuesday that it beat second-quarter forecasts but revised its outlook downward.
Adobe provided guidance for the current quarter well below Wall Street targets, and it lowered the upper end of its revenue growth range for the year. It blamed weakness in Europe.

"There's no doubt that Europe is going through economic turmoil and, like a lot of companies that have announced earnings recently, we're trying to be prudent about our guidance for that," Adobe Chief Financial Officer Mark Garrett told IBD.

Another factor weighing on near-term sales is the company's transition from a perpetual license to subscription business model for its flagship Creative Suite software. Historically, customers have purchased its software outright, often as a packaged "shrink-wrapped" product on discs at retail. But with Creative Suite 6, launched in May, Adobe is encouraging users to switch to a software-as-a-service model, where customers download the software and pay a monthly subscription fee to use it rather than buy it upfront.

"We're overachieving on our subscription sign-ups, which is great and that's very positive for the business," Garrett said. "The more people that subscribe, the more it drives recurring revenue and gives us a one-to-one relationship with our customers. So we really want to drive more people to subscription. If we overachieve on our subscription plan, it means we're going to have less perpetual (license) revenue, and you see a little bit of that in Q2."
As of June 1, Adobe had signed up more than 90,000 paid subscribers to Creative Suite 6 and Creative Cloud. It's adding more than 5,000 net new subscribers a week, Garrett says.

"That's fairly significant and a great start," Garrett said. "We have a ton of people who are signing up for the free trial download and the free monthly subscription and those are people that we can then market to and try to convert to being paid users."
Adobe expects that it can add 10% new users to its creative professional business this year.

The company's digital media business, which includes Creative Suite and individual products such as Photoshop, accounted for 73% of Adobe's $1.12 billion in sales in its fiscal second quarter. Digital media sales rose 8.5% from the year-earlier quarter.

Adobe's digital marketing business, which includes the former Omniture, accounted for 22% of sales last quarter. It was the San Jose, Calif.-based company's fastest-growing segment, with revenue up 17% from a year ago.
Adobe's print and publishing business contributed 5% of sales in Q2.

For the quarter ended June 1, Adobe earned 60 cents a share excluding items, up 9% from the year-ago quarter and a penny better than expected by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Sales rose 10% to $1.12 billion, edging analyst views of $1.11 billion.

For the current quarter, based on the midpoint of its guidance, Adobe now expects to earn 59 cents a share excluding items, on sales of $1.1 billion. Analysts had been targeting 61 cents, up 11%, on sales of $1.13 billion, up 12%.

For the fiscal year, Adobe narrowed its revenue growth target to 6% to 7%, vs. its prior target of 6% to 8%.Shares of Adobe Systems (ADBE) were down 3.7% in midday trading Wednesday, after being down as much as 7.6% earlier, following the graphic design software company's disclosure late Tuesday that it beat second-quarter forecasts but revised its outlook downward.Adobe provided guidance for the current quarter well below Wall Street targets, and it lowered the upper end of its revenue growth range for the year. It blamed weakness in Europe."There's no doubt that Europe is going through economic turmoil and, like a lot of companies that have announced earnings recently, we're trying to be prudent about our guidance for that," Adobe Chief Financial Officer Mark Garrett told IBD.Another factor weighing on near-term sales is the company's transition from a perpetual license to subscription business model for its flagship Creative Suite software. Historically, customers have purchased its software outright, often as a packaged "shrink-wrapped" product on discs at retail. But with Creative Suite 6, launched in May, Adobe is encouraging users to switch to a software-as-a-service model, where customers download the software and pay a monthly subscription fee to use it rather than buy it upfront."We're overachieving on our subscription sign-ups, which is great and that's very positive for the business," Garrett said. "The more people that subscribe, the more it drives recurring revenue and gives us a one-to-one relationship with our customers. So we really want to drive more people to subscription. If we overachieve on our subscription plan, it means we're going to have less perpetual (license) revenue, and you see a little bit of that in Q2."As of June 1, Adobe had signed up more than 90,000 paid subscribers to Creative Suite 6 and Creative Cloud. It's adding more than 5,000 net new subscribers a week, Garrett says."That's fairly significant and a great start," Garrett said. "We have a ton of people who are signing up for the free trial download and the free monthly subscription and those are people that we can then market to and try to convert to being paid users."Adobe expects that it can add 10% new users to its creative professional business this year.The company's digital media business, which includes Creative Suite and individual products such as Photoshop, accounted for 73% of Adobe's $1.12 billion in sales in its fiscal second quarter. Digital media sales rose 8.5% from the year-earlier quarter.Adobe's digital marketing business, which includes the former Omniture, accounted for 22% of sales last quarter. It was the San Jose, Calif.-based company's fastest-growing segment, with revenue up 17% from a year ago.Adobe's print and publishing business contributed 5% of sales in Q2.For the quarter ended June 1, Adobe earned 60 cents a share excluding items, up 9% from the year-ago quarter and a penny better than expected by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Sales rose 10% to $1.12 billion, edging analyst views of $1.11 billion.For the current quarter, based on the midpoint of its guidance, Adobe now expects to earn 59 cents a share excluding items, on sales of $1.1 billion. Have you been paying attention to shares of Intuit (INTU  -  Free Report)? Shares have been on the move, with the stock up 8.8% over the past month. INTU hit a new 52-week-high of $213.76 in the previous session. Intuit has gained 35.3% since the start of the year compared to the 9.3% move for the Computer and Technology sector and the 17.4% year-to-date return for its peer group.What's Driving the Outperformance?The stock has a great record of positive earnings surprises, having beaten the Zacks Consensus EPS estimate in each of the last four quarters. In its last earnings report on May 22, 2018, Intuit reported EPS of $4.82 vs.the Zacks Consensus of $4.67 while it beat the consensus revenue estimate by 2.91%.For the current fiscal year, Intuit is expected to post earnings of $5.53 per share on $5.93 billion in revenues. This represents a 25.4% change in EPS on a 14.51% change in revenues. For the next fiscal year, the company is expected to earn $6.52 per share on $6.51 billion in revenues. This represents a year-over-year change of 17.96% and 9.88%, respectively.Valuation MetricsIntuit may be at a 52-week-high right now, but what might the future hold for INTU? A key aspect of this question is taking a look at valuation metrics in order to determine if the company is due for a pullback from this level.On this front, we can look at the Zacks Style Scores, as these give investors a variety of ways to comb through stocks (beyond looking at the Zacks Rank of a security). These styles are represented by grades running from A to F in the categories of Value, Growth, and Momentum, while there is a combined VGM score as well. The idea behind the style scores is to help investors pick the most appropriate Zacks Rank stocks based on their individual investment style.Intuit has a Value Score of D. The stock's Growth and Momentum Scores are A and B, respectively, giving the company a VGM score of B.In terms of its value breakdown, the stock currently trades at 38.6X current fiscal year EPS estimates. On a trailing cash flow basis, the stock currently trades at 44.9X versus its peer group's average of 25.7X. Additionally, the stock has a PEG ratio of 2.38. This isn't enough to put the company in the top echelon of all stocks we cover from a value perspective.Zacks RankWe also need to look at the Zacks Rank for the stock, as this supersedes any trend on the style score front. Fortunately, Intuit currently has a Zacks Rank of #2 (Buy) thanks to rising earnings estimates.Since we recommend that investors select stocks carrying Zacks Rank of 1 (Strong Buy) or 2 (Buy) and Style Scores of A or B, it looks as if Intuit passes the test. Thus, it seems as though INTU shares could have potential in the weeks and months to come.How Does Intuit Stack Up to the Competition?Shares of Intuit have been rising, and the company still appears to be a decent choice, but what about the rest of the industry? Some of its industry peers are also looking good, including Verint Systems (VRNT  -  Free Report), SAP SE (SAP  -  Free Report), and Adobe Systems (ADBE  -  Free Report), all of which currently have a Zacks Rank of at least #2 and a VGM Score of at least B, making them well-rounded choices.The Zacks Computer-Software industry is in the top 29% of all the industries we have in our universe, so it looks like there are some nice tailwinds for INTU, even beyond its own solid fundamental situation.

Growth stocks can be some of the most exciting picks in the market, as these high-flyers can captivate investors’ attention, and produce big gains as well. However, they can also lead on the downside when the growth story is over, so it is important to find companies which are still seeing strong growth prospects in their businesses.One such company that might be well-positioned for future earnings growth is Adobe Systems Incorporated (ADBE  -  Free Report). This firm, which is in the Computer - Software industry, saw EPS growth of 43.2% last year, and is looking great for this year too.In fact, the current growth estimate for this year calls for earnings-per-share growth of 53.6%. Furthermore, the long-term growth rate is currently an impressive 16.2%, suggesting pretty good prospects for the long haul.Adobe Systems Incorporated Price and Consensus Adobe Systems Incorporated Price and Consensus | Adobe Systems Incorporated QuoteAnd if this wasn’t enough, the stock has actually seen estimates rise over the past month for the current fiscal year by about 3.6%. Thanks to this rise in earnings estimates, ADBE has a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) which further underscores the potential for outperformance in this company. You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1(Strong Buy) Rank stocks here.So, if you are looking for a fast-growing stock that is still seeing plenty of opportunities on the horizon, make sure to consider ADBE. The Computer Software industry is benefiting from continued strong digital transformation demand environment.Software has become the focal point of technological innovation. The last few years have witnessed a series of breakthroughs in cloud computing, predictive analysis, artificial intelligence (AI), self-driving vehicles, digital personal assistants and Internet of Things (IoT), consequently setting the stage for strong growth in the software industry.Moreover, continued enterprise investment in big data and analytics along with the ongoing adoption of Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) presents significant growth opportunity for industry players.Notably, the cloud offers a flexible and cost-effective platform to develop and test new applications and the deployment time is also much shorter as compared with legacy systems.Additionally, the increasing need to secure cloud platforms, amid growing incidences of cyber attacks and hacking, continues to drive demand for cyber security software.Further, as enterprises continue to move their on-premise workload to cloud environments (emergence of hybrid cloud), application and infrastructure monitoring have gained utmost importance. This is creating more demand for performance management monitoring tools that are not only scalable but also suitable for cloud-based environments.Industry Returns PositiveRobust demand for software and continuing innovations have been the key catalysts to consistent earnings and impressive sales growth. These are mainly behind investor confidence instilled in the Computer Software industry’s growth prospects.The Zacks Computer Software Industry, within the broader Zacks Computer And Technology Sector, has outperformed both the S&P 500 and its own sector over the past year.One-Year Price PerformanceWhile the stocks in this industry have collectively gained 34.1%, the Zacks S&P 500 Composite and Zacks Computer And Technology Sector have rallied 13.7% and 19.2%, respectively.We believe the near-term growth prospects are bright given increased spending by enterprises on software procurement.Stretched Valuation a ConcernHowever, the Computer Software industry’s valuation looks stretched at the moment. One might get a good sense of the industry’s relative valuation by looking at its price-to-earnings ratio (P/E), which essentially shows how much an investor is willing to pay for each unit of earnings.Notably, a lower P/E ratio is always better.The industry currently has a forward 12-month P/E ratio of 26.65, which is close to the highest level over the past year.The space also looks expensive when compared with the market at large, as the forward 12-month P/E ratio for the S&P 500 is 17.14 and the median level is 18.28.Price-to-Earnings Ratio (F12M) Moreover, a comparison of the group’s P/E ratio with that of its border sector ensures that the group is trading at a huge premium. The Zacks Computer And Technology Sector’s forward 12-month P/E ratio of 19.71 and the median level of 20.50 for the same period are way below the Zacks Computer Software Industry’s respective ratios.Price-to-Earnings Ratio (F12M) Improving Earnings Outlook to Drive OutperformanceNevertheless, strong industry fundamentals and expectations of solid top-line growth should help Computer Software stocks continue generating positive shareholder returns in the near future.Investors would also be eager to watch whether this group has the potential to perform better than the broader market in the quarters ahead. One reliable measure that can help investors understand the industry’s prospects is the earnings outlook for its member companies. Empirical research shows that a company’s earnings outlook significantly influences the performance of its stock.One could get a good sense of a company’s earnings outlook by comparing the consensus earnings expectation for the current financial year with the last year’s reported number, but an effective measure could be the magnitude and direction of the recent change in earnings estimates.The consensus earnings estimate for the Zacks Computer Software industry of $3.13 per share reflects solid year-over-year improvement. Moreover, the trend in earnings estimates revisions have been favorable of late.Price and Consensus: Zacks Computer Software IndustryLooking at the aggregate earnings estimate revisions, it appears that analysts are gaining confidence in this group’s earnings potential.The consensus EPS estimate for the current fiscal year has been revised 2.6% upward since Mar 31, 2018.Current Fiscal Year EPS Estimate Revisions Zacks Industry Rank Indicates Solid ProspectsThe group’s Zacks Industry Rank, which is basically the average of the Zacks Rank of all the member stocks, indicates continued outperformance in the near term.The Zacks Computer Software industry currently carries a Zacks Industry Rank #63, which places it at the top 25% of more than 256 Zacks industries. Our research shows that the top 50% of the Zacks-ranked industries outperforms the bottom 50% by a factor of more than 2 to 1.Our proprietary Heat Map shows that the industry’s rank has continuously improved over the past five weeks.Long-Term Growth Prospects StrongThe long-term (3-5 years) EPS growth estimate for the Zacks Computer Software industry appears promising. The group’s mean estimate of long-term EPS growth rate has remained steady since March 2018 to reach the current level of 11.89%. This compares to 9.8% for the Zacks S&P 500 composite.Mean Estimate of Long-Term EPS Growth Rate Computer Software’s long-term growth prospects are alluring. Growing adoption of hybrid cloud computing models, rapid usage of AI and machine learning tools, the proliferation of wearables & self-driving vehicles and increasing automation of the application development process bode well for the industry.Moreover, the growing usage of Internet of Things (IoT) at home, in office, for cars and every other conceivable place is also an incredible business driver. These factors are expected to drive top-line growth that has gained significant momentum since the end of 2016.  Moreover, another indication of solid long-term prospects is the improvement in the group’s gross margin. Bottom LineThe role of software is evolving. Apart from running devices and applications, its usage is expanding in managing infrastructure. Moreover, the industry is significantly benefiting from the ongoing cloud transition.SaaS companies are expected to register strong top-line growth due to a higher percentage of recurring revenues, subscription gross margin and a lower churn rate. Moreover, strong spending by enterprises is a positive.Moreover, software companies are poised to benefit the most from Trump's repatriation policy. This enhanced liquidity is expected to boost their appetite for strategic acquisitions.Despite stretched valuations, investors can build positions in the Computer Software industry based on the above-mentioned factors as well as strong earnings outlook.Here, we list four stocks that have been witnessing positive earnings estimate revisions and carry a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) or 2 (Buy).(You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1 Rank stocks here.)ANSYS, Inc. (ANSS  -  Free Report): The stock of this Pittsburgh, PA-based engineering simulation software and services provider has jumped 45.1% over the past year. The Zacks Consensus Estimate for the current-year EPS has increased 1.9% over the last 60 days.Price and Consensus: ANSS Citrix Systems, Inc. The stock has rallied 32.4% over the past year.Price and Consensus: CTXS Cadence Design Systems, Inc.
